revision.text:
{{Redirect|Dobrudzha|the [[Association football|football]] team|PFC Dobrudzha Dobrich}} {{Redirect|Dobrogea|the village in [[Chișinău]] municipality, [[Moldova]]|Sîngera}}
[[File:Dobruja in Europe map.svg|thumb|350px|Dobruja (dark green) within [[Romania]] and [[Bulgaria]] (light green) both in Eastern Europe]] [[File:Stema_Dobrogei.png|thumb|200px| Coat of arms of the Romanian Dobruja]]
'''Dobruja''' or '''Dobrudja''' ({{lang-bg|Добруджа}}, transliterated: ''Dobrudzha'' or ''Dobrudža''; {{lang-ro|Dobrogea}} {{IPA-ro|ˈdobrod͡ʒe̯a|pron|Ro-Dobrogea.ogg}} <small>or</small> {{IPA-ro|doˈbrod͡ʒe̯a|}}; {{lang-tr|Dobruca}}) is a historical region in [[Eastern Europe]] that has been divided since the 19th century between the territories of [[Bulgaria]] and [[Romania]]. It is situated between the lower [[Danube]] River and the [[Black Sea]], and includes the [[Danube Delta]], [[Romania]]n coast, and the northernmost part of the [[Bulgarian Black Sea Coast|Bulgarian coast]]. The territory of Dobruja is made up of [[Northern Dobruja]], which is part of Romania, and [[Southern Dobruja]], which belongs to Bulgaria.
The territory of the Romanian region '''Dobrogea''' is organised as the counties of [[Constanța County|Constanța]] and [[Tulcea County|Tulcea]], with a combined area of 15,500 km<sup>2</sup> (6,011 sq. miles) and a population of slightly less than 900 thousand. Its main cities are [[Constanța]], [[Tulcea]], [[Medgidia]] and [[Mangalia]]. Dobrogea is represented by [[dolphin]]s in the [[coat of arms of Romania]].
The Bulgarian region '''Dobrudzha''' is divided among the administrative regions of [[Dobrich Province|Dobrich]] and [[Silistra Province|Silistra]]; the following villages of [[Razgrad Province]]: Konevo, Rainino, Terter and Madrevo; and the village General Kantardzhievo ([[Varna Province|Varna]]). This section has a total area of 7,565 km<sup>2</sup>, with a combined population of some 310,000 people, the main towns being [[Dobrich]] and [[Silistra]] (regional seats).
== Geography == [[File:Dobrudja topographic map-en.svg|thumb|Geographical map of Dobruja]] [[File:On The Way Back.jpg|thumb|Woods and agricultural land in the Northern Dobruja Plateau]] [[File:DobrujaLandscape.jpg|thumb|Steppe and agricultural land in the Central Dobruja Plateau]] [[File:Yaylata.jpg|thumb|Rocky shores characteristic for the Southern Dobrujan coast]] With the exception of the [[Danube Delta]], a marshy region located in its northeastern corner, Dobruja is hilly, with an average altitude of about 200–300 metres. The highest point is the Țuțuiatu (Greci) Peak in the [[Măcin Mountains]], having a height of 467 m. The [[Dobrogea Plateau]] covers most of the Romanian part of Dobruja. The [[Ludogorie Plateau]] is found in Bulgaria. [[Lake Razelm]] is one of the most important lakes in Northern Dobruja.
Dobruja lies in the temperate [[continental climate|continental]] climatic area; the local [[climate]] is determined by the influx of oceanic air from the northwest and northeast and continental air from the [[East European Plain]]. Dobruja's relatively level terrain and its bare location<!-- meaning unforested? --> facilitate the influx of humid, warm air in the spring, summer and autumn from the northwest, as well as that of northern and northeastern polar air in the winter. The Black Sea also exerts an influence over the region's climate, particularly within 40–60 kilometres from the coast. The average annual temperatures range from 11 °C inland and along the Danube, to 11.8 °C on the coast and less than 10 °C in the higher parts of the plateau. The coastal region of Southern Dobruja is the most arid part of Bulgaria, with an annual [[Precipitation (meteorology)|precipitation]] of 450 millimetres.
Dobruja is a windy region once known for its [[windmill]]s. There is wind during about 85–90% of all days; it usually comes from the north or northeast. The average wind speed is about twice higher than the average in Bulgaria. Due to the limited precipitation and the proximity to the sea, rivers in Dobruja are usually short and with low discharge. The region has a number of shallow seaside lakes with [[brackish water]].<ref name=fol>{{cite book|last=Фол|first=Александър|title=История на Добруджа (History of Dobruja)|publisher=[[Bulgarian Academy of Sciences]]|location=[[Sofia]]|year=1984|oclc=165781151}}</ref>
== Etymology == The most widespread opinion among scholars is that the origin of the term ''Dobruja'' is to be found in the Turkish rendition of the name of a 14th‑century Bulgarian ruler, [[Despot (court title)|despot]] [[Dobrotitsa]].<ref>A. Ischirkoff, ''Les Bulgares en Dobroudja'', p. 4, attributes this opinion, among others, to [[Johann Christian von Engel]], [[Felix Philipp Kanitz]], [[Marin Drinov]], [[Josef Jireček]], [[Grigore Tocilescu]] <!--to be identified: Sassi, Syrcou, A.T. Ilieff--></ref><ref>[[Paul Wittek]], ''Yazijioghlu 'Ali on the Christian Turks of the Dobruja'', p. 639</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Davidova|first=R.|title=История на Добруджа|editor1-first=Aleksander|editor1-last=Fol|editor2-first=Strashimir|editor2-last=Dimitrov|publisher=Bulgarian Academy of Sciences|year=1984|volume=1|page=9|chapter=Приподно-географски условия в Добруджа|oclc=11916334|language=Bulgarian}}</ref> It was common for the Turks to name countries after one of their early rulers (for example, nearby [[Moldavia]] was known as ''Bogdan [[Vlachs#Wallachia|Iflak]]'' by the Turks, named after [[Bogdan I of Moldavia|Bogdan I]]). Other etymologies have been considered, but never gained widespread acceptance.
[[Abdolonyme Ubicini]] believed the name meant "good lands", derived from [[Slavic languages|Slavic]] ''dobro'' ("good"), an opinion that was adopted by several 19th‑century scholars. This derivation appears to contrast with the usual 19th‑century description of Dobruja as a dry barren land; it has been explained as expressing the point of view of [[Ruthenes]], who considered the Danube delta in the northern Dobruja as a significant improvement over the [[steppes]] to the North.<ref>A. Ischirkoff, ''Les Bulgares en Dobroudja'', p. 4, attributes this opinion to [[Camille Allard]], [[Ami Boué]], [[Heinrich Brunn]]</ref> [[I. A. Nazarettean]] combines the Slavic word with the [[Crimean Tatar language|Tatar]] ''budjak'' ("corner"), thus proposing the etymology "good corner".
A version matching contemporaneous descriptions was suggested by [[Felix Philipp Kanitz|Kanitz]], who associated the name with the [[Bulgarian language|Bulgarian]] ''dobrice'' ("rocky and unproductive terrain").<ref>G. Dănescu, ''Dobrogea (La Dobroudja). Étude de Géographie physique et ethnographique'', pp. 35–36</ref> According to [[Gheorghe I. Brătianu]], the name is a Slavic derivation from the Turkic word ''Bordjan'' or ''Brudjars'', which referred to the Turkic [[Proto-Bulgarians]]; this term was also used by Arabic writers.
One of the earliest documented uses of the name can be found in the [[Ottoman Turkish language|Turkish]] ''Oghuz-name'' narrative, dated to the 15th century, where it appears as ''Dobruja-éli''. The [[possessive suffix]] ''el-i'' indicated that the land was considered as belonging to Dobrotitsa ("{{lang|ota|دوبرجه}}" in the original Ottoman Turkish).<ref>Paul Wittek, ''Yazijioghlu 'Ali on the Christian Turks of the Dobruja'', p. 653</ref> The loss of the final particle is not unusual in the Turkish world, a similar evolution being observed in the name of [[Aydın]], originally ''Aydın-éli''.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia | last = İnalcık | first = Halil | authorlink = Halil İnalcık | title = Dobru<u>dj</u>a | encyclopedia = [[Encyclopaedia of Islam]] | volume = II | page = 610 a | publisher = [[Brill Publishers|E. J. Brill]] | location = Leiden |year=1998 |isbn=978-90-04-07026-4}}</ref> Another early use is in the 16th‑century [[Latin language|Latin]] translation of [[Laonicus Chalcondyles]]' ''Histories'', where the term ''Dobroditia'' is used for the original [[Medieval Greek|Greek]] "Dobrotitsa's country" ({{lang|el|Δοβροτίκεω χώρα}}).<ref>A. Ischirkoff, ''Les Bulgares en Dobroudja'', p. 4</ref> In the 17th century, the region was referred to in more accounts, with renditions such as ''Dobrucia'', ''Dobrutcha'', ''Dobrus'', ''Dobruccia'', ''Dobroudja'', ''Dobrudscha'', and others being used by foreign authors.<ref>A. Ischirkoff, ''Les Bulgares en Dobroudja'', pp. 5–7</ref>
Initially, the name meant just the steppe of the southern region, between the forests around [[Babadag]] in the north and the [[Silistra]]–[[Dobrich]]–[[Balchik]] line in the south.<ref>{{cite book |first=Camille |last=Allard |title=Mission médicale dans la Tatarie-Dobroutscha|location=Paris|year=1857|pages= 7–8|oclc=36764237|language=French}}</ref> Eventually, the term was extended to include the northern part and the [[Danube Delta]].<ref>{{cite book|first=Robert |last= Stănciugel |author2=Bălaşa, Liliana Monica |title=Dobrogea în Secolele VII–XIX. Evoluţie istorică|location=Bucureşti |publisher=|language=Romanian|year = 2005|pages=68–70}}</ref> In the 19th century, some authors used the name to refer just to the territory between the southernmost branch of the Danube (St. George) in the north and the Karasu Valley (nowadays the [[Danube-Black Sea Canal]]) in the south.<ref>{{cite book |first=Thomas|last=Forester|title=The Danube and the Black Sea: Memoir on Their Junction by a Railway between Tchernavoda and a Free Port at Kustendje|location=London|publisher=Edward Stanford|year=1857|page=96|oclc=26010612}}</ref>
== History ==
=== Prehistory === The territory of Dobruja has been inhabited by humans since [[Middle Paleolithic|Middle]] and [[Upper Paleolithic|Upper Palaeolithic]],<ref>A. Rădulescu, I. Bitoleanu, ''Istoria Dobrogei'', p. 13</ref> as the remains at Babadag, [[Slava Rusă]] and [[Enisala]] demonstrate. In the [[Neolithic]], the territory was occupied by members of the [[Hamangia culture]] (named after a village on the Dobrujan coast), [[Boian culture]] and [[Karanovo culture|Karanovo V]] culture. At the end of the fifth millennium BC, under the influence of some Aegeo-Mediterranean tribes and cultures, the [[Gumelniţa culture]] appeared in the region. In the [[Eneolithic]], populations migrating from the north of the Black Sea, of the [[Kurgan]] culture, mixed with the previous population, creating the [[Cernavodă culture|Cernavodă I]] culture. Under Kurgan II influence, the Cernavodă II culture emerged. Through the combination of the Cernavodă I and [[Ezero culture]]s, the Cernavodă III culture developed. The region had commercial contacts with the Mediterranean world since the 14th century BC, as proven by a [[Mycenae]]an sword discovered at [[Medgidia]].<ref>A. Rădulescu, I. Bitoleanu, ''Istoria Dobrogei'', p. 30</ref>
=== Ancient history === [[File:Cetatea Histria Constanta.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Ruins of the first Greek colony in the region, [[Histria (Sinoe)|Istros]]]]
During the early [[Iron Age]] (8th–6th centuries BC), there was increased differentiation of the local [[Getic]] tribes from the [[Thracians|Thracian]] mass. In the second part of the 8th century BC, the first signs of commercial relations between the indigenous population and the Greeks appeared on the shore of the Halmyris Gulf (now the [[Sinoe Lake]]).
In 657/656 BC [[Ancient Greek]] colonists from [[Miletus]] founded a colony in the region: [[Histria (Sinoe)|Histria]].<ref>{{Cite book |author=Eusebios–Hieronymos|authorlink=Jerome|editor=Ibarez, Josh Miguel Blasco |title=Hieronymi Chronicon |page=167 |url=http://www.tertullian.org/fathers/jerome_chronicle_05_latin_part1.htm |year=2005 |accessdate=2007-04-27|language=Latin}}</ref> In the 7th and 6th centuries BC, more [[Greek colonies]] were founded on the Dobrujan coast ([[Callatis]], [[Constanța|Tomis]], [[Nesebar|Mesembria]], [[Dionysopolis]], Parthenopolis, Aphrodisias, Eumenia etc.). In the 5th century BC these colonies were under the influence of the [[Delian League]], passing in this period from [[oligarchy]] to [[Athenian democracy|democracy]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Aristotle |authorlink=Aristotle |title=Aristotle's Politics |editor=Jowett, Benjamin |chapter="Politics", Book V, 6 |url=http://ebooks.adelaide.edu.au/a/aristotle/a8po/ |chapterurl=http://ebooks.library.adelaide.edu.au/a/aristotle/a8po/book5.html |year=2000 |location=Adelaide |publisher=University of Adelaide |accessdate=2007-04-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080222064513/http://ebooks.adelaide.edu.au/a/aristotle/a8po/ |archivedate=February 22, 2008 }}</ref> In the 6th century BC, the first [[Scythians|Scythian groups]] began to enter the region. Two [[Getae]] tribes, the ''Crobyzi'' and ''Terizi'', and the town of Orgame ([[Argamum]]) were mentioned on the territory of present Dobruja by [[Hecataeus of Miletus|Hekataios of Miletus]] (540–470 BC).<ref>[[Karl Wilhelm Ludwig Müller|C. Müller]], ''Fragmenta historicorum Graecorum'', Paris, 1841, I, pp. 170–173</ref>
In 514/512 BC King [[Darius I of Persia]] subdued the [[Getae]] living in the region during his expedition against Scythians living north of the Danube.<ref>{{cite book |author=Herodotus |authorlink=Herodotus|title=Herodotus|editor=Godley, A. D.|chapter=''The Histories'', Book IV, 93|location=Cambridge|publisher=Harvard University Press|year=1920|accessdate=2007-04-28| oclc=1610641 |chapterurl=http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/cgi-bin/ptext?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0126&layout=&query=chapter%3D%23657&loc=4.92.1}}</ref> At about 430 BC, the [[Odrysian kingdom]] under [[Sitalkes]] extended its rule to the mouths of the Danube.<ref>{{cite book |author=Thucydides|authorlink=Thucydides|title=History of the Peloponnesian war|editor=Crawley, Richard|chapter=''The Peloponnesian War'', Book II, Ch. 97|location=London|publisher=J.M. Dent|year=1910|oclc=7727833 |url=http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/cgi-bin/ptext?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0200;query=toc;layout=;loc=2.97.1|chapterurl=http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/cgi-bin/ptext?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0200&layout=&query=chapter%3D%23243&loc=2.98.1 |accessdate=2007-04-30}}</ref> In 429 BC, Getae from the region participated in an Odrysian campaign in [[Macedon]]ia.<ref>Thucydides, ''The Peloponnesian War'', [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/cgi-bin/ptext?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0200;query=chapter%3D%23244;layout=;loc=2.99.1 Book VII, Ch. 98]</ref> In the 4th century BC, the Scythians brought Dobruja under their sway. In 341–339 BC, one of their kings, [[Atheas]], fought against Histria, which was supported by a ''Histrianorum rex'' (probably a local Getic ruler). In 339 BC, King Atheas was defeated by the [[Macedon]]ians under King [[Philip II of Macedon|Philip II]], who afterwards extended his rule over Dobruja.<ref>{{cite book |author=Marcus Junianus Justinus|authorlink=Junianus Justinus|title=Justin, Cornelius Nepos, and Eutropius|editor=Watson, John Selby|chapter=''Epitome of the Philippic History of Pompeius Trogus'', Book IX, 2|chapterurl=http://www.tertullian.org/fathers/justinus_03_books01to10.htm|accessdate=2007-04-30|oclc=11259464|location=London| publisher=H.G. Bohn|year=1853|pages=81–82}}</ref> [[File:Scythia Minor map-en.svg|left|thumb|Ancient towns and colonies in [[Scythia Minor]].]] In 313 BC and again in 310–309 BC, the Greek colonies led by Callatis, supported by [[Antigonus I Monophthalmus]], revolted against Macedonian rule. The revolts were suppressed by [[Lysimachus]], the [[diadochi|diadochus]] of [[Thrace#Ancient_and_Roman_history|Thrace]], who also began a military expedition against [[Dromichaetes]], the ruler of the Getae north of the Danube, in 300 BC. In the 3rd century BC, colonies on the Dobrujan coast paid tribute to the [[basileus|basilei]] [[Zalmodegikos]] and [[Moskon]], who probably also ruled northern Dobruja. In the same century, [[Celts]] settled in the north of the region. In 260 BC, [[Byzantion]] lost the war with Callatis and Histria for the control of Tomis. At the end of the 3rd century BC and the beginning of the 2nd century BC, the [[Bastarnae]] settled in the area of the Danube Delta. Around 200 BC, the Thracian king [[Zoltes]] invaded the province several times, but was defeated by [[Rhemaxos]], who became the protector of the Greek colonies.
Early Greek scholars such as [[Herodotus]] appear to have regarded the region as the a south-western extension of [[Scythia]] – a practice also followed in a 2nd Century BC inscription, recording a decree made in Histria, which refers to the region surrounding the Greek city as ''Scythia''. However, the [[toponym]] Μικρά Σκυθία ''Mikrá Skythia'', usually translated as [[Scythia Minor]] or Lesser Scythia, appears to have become the name for the specific region later known as Dobruja. The earliest known usage of the name "Scythia Minor" (''Mikrá Skythia'') is found in [[Strabo]]'s early ''Geography'' (1st century AD). The Greeks thus apparently distinguished it from ''Scythia Major'', which lay north of the Danube delta.
Around 100 BC King [[Mithridates VI of Pontus]] extended his authority over the Greek cities in Dobruja. However, in 72–71 BC, during the [[Third Mithridatic War]], these cities were occupied by the forces of [[Marcus Terentius Varro Lucullus]], the [[Roman Empire|Roman]] [[proconsul]] of [[Macedonia (Roman province)|Macedonia]]. A [[foedus]] was signed between the Greek colonies and the [[Roman Empire]], but in 62–61 BC the colonies revolted{{citation needed|date=May 2017}}. [[Gaius Antonius Hybrida]] intervened, but was defeated by Getae and Bastarnae near Histria. After 55 BC the [[Dacians]] under King [[Burebista]] conquered Dobruja and all the Greek colonies on the coast. Their rule ended in 44 BC{{citation needed|date=May 2017}}.
=== Roman rule === In 28/29 BC [[Rholes]], a [[Getae|Getic]] ruler from southern Dobruja, supported the proconsul of Macedonia, [[Marcus Licinius Crassus (consul 30 BC)|Marcus Licinius Crassus]], in his action against the Bastarnae. Declared ''friend and ally of the Roman people'' by [[Octavian]],<ref>{{cite book|author=Cassius Dio|authorlink=Cassius Dio|title=Dio's Roman History, Vol VI|editor1=Cary, Earnest |editor2=Foster, Herbert Baldwin |series=The Loeb classical library|location=Cambridge, Mass|publisher=Harvard University Press|year=1917|chapter=Book LI, Ch. 24 |chapterurl=http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Cassius_Dio/51*.html |pages=71–72|oclc=688941}}</ref> Rholes helped Crassus in conquering the states of [[Dapyx]] (in central Dobruja) and [[Zyraxes]] (in the north of the region).<ref>Cassius Dio, ''Roman History'', Book LI, Ch. 26, Vol VI, pp. 75–77</ref> Dobruja became part of the [[Client state|client kingdom]] of the Odrysians, while the Greek cities on the coast came under direct rule of the governor of [[Macedonia (Roman province)|Macedonia]]. In 12 AD and 15 AD, Getic armies succeeded in conquering the cities of [[Tulcea|Aegyssus]] and [[Troesmis]] for a short time, but Odrysian king [[Rhoemetalces I]] defeated them with the help of the Roman army. [[File:Cetatea Tropaeum Traiani - vedere laterală.jpg|thumb|200px|right|The [[Tropaeum Traiani]] monument in [[Adamclisi]] commemorating Roman victory over Dacians (Modern reconstruction)]] In 15 AD the Roman province of [[Moesia]] was created, but Dobruja, under the name ''Ripa Thraciae'' remained part of the [[Odrysian]] kingdom. The Greek cities on the coast formed a ''[[Prefect#Ancient_Rome|praefectura orae maritimae]]''. In 46 AD [[Thracia]] became a Roman province and the territories of present Dobruja were absorbed into the province of Moesia. The [[Geto–Dacians]] invaded the region several times in the 1st century AD, especially between 62 and 70. In the same period, the base of the [[Roman navy|Roman Danube fleet]] (''classis Flavia Moesica'') was moved to [[Isaccea|Noviodunum]]. The ''praefectura'' was annexed to Moesia in 86 AD. In the same year [[Domitian]] divided Moesia, Dobruja being included in the eastern part, ''[[Moesia Inferior]]''.
In the winter of 101–102 the Dacian king [[Decebalus]] led a coalition of Dacians, [[Carpians]], [[Sarmatians]] and [[Burs (Dacia)|Burs]] in an attack against Moesia Inferior. The invading army was defeated by the Roman legions under Emperor [[Trajan]] on the [[Yantra River|Yantra]] river. (Later [[Nicopolis ad Istrum]] was founded there to commemorate the victory.) The invaders were also defeated near the modern village of [[Adamclisi]], in the southern part of Dobruja. The latter victory was commemorated by the [[Tropaeum Traiani|a monument]], built in 109 at the site, and the founding of the city of Tropaeum. After 105, [[Legio XI Claudia]] and [[Legio V Macedonica]] were moved to Dobruja, at [[Durostorum]] and Troesmis, respectively.
In 118 [[Hadrian]] intervened in the region to calm a Sarmatian rebellion. In 170 [[Costoboci]] invaded Dobruja, attacking [[Libida]], [[Ulmetum]] and [[Tropaeum Traiani|Tropaeum]]. The province was generally stable and prosperous until the [[crisis of the Third Century]], which led to the weakening of defences and numerous barbarian invasions. In 248 a coalition of [[Goths]], Carpians, [[Taifali]], Bastarnae and [[Hasdingi]], led by Argaithus and Guntheric, devastated Dobruja.<ref>{{cite book |author=Iordanes |authorlink=Jordanes|editor=[[Charles Christopher Mierow]]|title=The origin and deeds of the Goths in English version|url=http://www.acs.ucalgary.ca/~vandersp/Courses/texts/jordgeti.html|chapter=Ch. XVI |chapterurl=http://www.acs.ucalgary.ca/~vandersp/Courses/texts/jordgeti.html#XVI|pages=sect. 91–92|location=Princeton |year=1908|publisher=Princeton University Press|accessdate=2007-04-30|oclc=24312572 |nopp=true}}</ref> During the reign of [[Decius|Trajan Decius]] the province suffered greatly from the attack of Goths under King [[Cniva]].<ref>Iordanes, ''The Origin and Deeds of the Goths'', [http://www.acs.ucalgary.ca/~vandersp/Courses/texts/jordgeti.html#XVIII Ch. XVIII], sect. 101–102</ref> Barbarian attacks followed in 258, 263 and 267. In 269 a fleet of allied Goths, [[Heruli]], [[Bastarnae]] and Sarmatians attacked the cities on the coast, including Tomis.<ref>{{cite book |author=Zosimos|authorlink=Zosimus|title=The History of Count Zosimus, Sometime Advocate and Chancellor of the Roman Empire|chapter=Book I|location=London|year=1814|publisher=Printed for J. Davis by W. Green and T. Chaplin|oclc=56628978|chapterurl=http://www.tertullian.org/fathers/zosimus01_book1.htm|page=22}}</ref> In 272 [[Aurelian]] defeated the Carpians north of the Danube and settled a part of them near [[Hârşova|Carsium]]. The same emperor put an end to the crisis in the Roman Empire, thus helping the reconstruction of the province.
During the reign of [[Diocletian]], Dobruja was organized administratively as a separate province, called [[Scythia Minor|Scythia]], part of the [[Diocese]] of Thracia. Its capital city was Tomis. Diocletian transferred [[Legio II Herculia]] to Troesmis and [[Legio I Iovia]] to Noviodunum. In 331–332 [[Constantine the Great]] defeated the Goths who attacked the province. But Dobruja was devastated again by [[Ostrogoths]] in 384–386. Under the Roman emperors [[Licinius]], [[Julian the Apostate]], and [[Valens]], the cities of the region were repaired or rebuilt.
=== Byzantine rule === After the division of the [[Roman Empire]], Dobruja was absorbed into the [[Eastern Roman Empire]]. Between 513 and 520, the region participated in a revolt against [[Anastasius I (emperor)|Anastasius I]]. Its leader, [[Vitalian (general)|Vitalian]], native of [[Zaldapa]] in Southern Dobruja, defeated the Byzantine general [[Hypatius (consul 500)|Hypatius]] near [[Kaliakra]]. During [[Justin I]]'s rule, [[Antes (people)|Antes]] and [[Early Slavs|Slavs]] invaded the region, but [[Germanus Justinus]] defeated them. In 529, the [[Gepid]] commander [[Mundus (general)|Mundus]] repelled a new invasion by [[Bulgars]] and Antes. [[Kutrigurs]] and [[Avars (Carpathians)|Avars]] invaded the region several times, until 561–562, when the Avars under [[Bayan I]] were settled south of the Danube as [[foederati]]. During the rule of [[Maurice (emperor)|Mauricius Tiberius]], the Slavs devastated Dobruja, destroying the cities of [[Dorostolon]], Zaldapa and Tropaeum. In 591/593, Byzantine general [[Priscus (general)|Priscus]] tried to stop invasions, attacking and defeating the Slavs under [[Ardagast]] in the north of the province. In 602 during the mutiny of the Byzantine army in the Balkans under [[Phocas]], a large mass of Slavs crossed the Danube, settling south of the Danube. Dobruja remained under loose Byzantine control, and was reorganised during the reign of [[Constantine IV]] as ''[[Theme (Byzantine district)|Thema]] Scythia''.<ref>{{cite book |author=Constantine Porphyrogennetos |authorlink=Constantine VII |script-title=el:Του σοφωτάτου δεσπότου και αυτοκράτορος Κωνσταντίνου, του Πορφυρογεννήτου, τα ευρισκόμενα πάντα. Τομ. β |series=Patrologiae cursus completus v.113 |editor=Migne, J. P. |chapter=Περί των Θεμάτων (De thematibus) |chapterurl=http://patrologia.ct.aegean.gr/PG_Migne/Constantinus%20Porphyrogenitus_PG%20112-113/De%20thematibus.pdf#page=12 |language=Greek |accessdate=2007-05-01 |year=1864 |oclc=54878095 |location=Paris |publisher=Apud Garnier Fratres, editores et J.-P. Migne, successores |url=http://patrologia.ct.aegean.gr/PG_Migne/Constantinus%20Porphyrogenitus_PG%20112-113/De%20thematibus.pdf |title=Archived copy |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070710003442/http://patrologia.ct.aegean.gr/PG_Migne/Constantinus%20Porphyrogenitus_PG%20112-113/De%20thematibus.pdf#page=12 |archivedate=July 10, 2007 |df= }} </ref>
=== First Bulgarian Empire rule === [[File:Мемориален комплекс "Хан Аспарух" (2), гр. Добрич.JPG|right|thumb|300px|Monument to [[Asparukh of Bulgaria|Asparukh]], the founder of the First Bulgarian State, in [[Dobrich]]; Dobruja was part of Asparukh's conquest in the 7th century]] The results of archaeological researches indicate that the Byzantine presence in Dobruja's mainland and on the banks of Danube was reduced in the end of the 6th century, under the pressure of the [[Migration Period]]. In the coastal fortifications on the southern bank of Danube, the latest Byzantine coin found dates from the time of the emperors [[Tiberius II Constantine]] (574–582) and [[Heraclius]] (610–641). After that period, all inland Byzantine cities were demolished by the invaders and abandoned.<ref>S. Vaklinov, "Формиране на старобългарската култура VI–XI век", p. 65</ref>
Some of the earliest [[Slavic peoples|Slavic]] settlements to the south of Danube have been discovered in Dobruja, near the villages of [[Popina, Silistra|Popina]], [[Garvăn]] and [[Nova Cherna]]. They have been dated to the end of the 6th and the beginning of the 7th centuries.<ref>S. Vaklinov, "Формиране на старобългарската култура VI–XI век", pp. 48-50</ref> These lands became the main zone of compact [[Bulgars|Bulgar]] settlement in the end of the 7th century.<ref>S. Vaklinov, "Формиране на старобългарската култура VI–XI век", p. 64</ref>
According to the peace treaty of 681, signed after the Bulgarian victory over Byzantines in the [[Battle of Ongala]], Dobruja became part of the [[First Bulgarian Empire]].<ref>I. Barnea, Şt.Ştefănescu, ''Bizantini, romani și bulgari la Dunărea de Jos'', p. 28</ref> Shortly after, the Bulgar founded the city of [[Pliska]], which became the first Bulgarian capital, near the southern border of Dobruja.<ref>Petar Mutafchiev, ''Добруджа. Сборник от Студии'', Sofia, <!-- unformatted--></ref> They rebuilt [[Madara (village)|Madara]] as a major Bulgar pagan religious centre.<ref>Веселин Бешевлиев, "Формиране на старобългарската култура VI-XI век", София, 1977, стр. 97–103.</ref> According to the ''[[Anonymous Bulgarian Chronicle#11th/12th_centuries|Bulgarian Apocryphal Chronicle]]'', from the 11th century, Bulgarian Tsar [[Asparukh of Bulgaria|Ispor]] "accepted the Bulgarian tsardom", created "great cities, [[Silistra|Drastar]] on the Danube", a "great wall from Danube to the sea", "the city of [[Pliska]]" and "populated the lands of [[Karvuna]]".<ref>{{cite book|last=Petkanova|first=Donka|title=Стара българска литература. Апокрифи|chapter=Българско творчество в традициите на апокрифите. Български апокрифен летопис|location=Sofia|publisher=Български писател|year=1981|oclc=177289940|language=Bulgarian}}</ref>
According to Bulgarian historians, during the 7th–10th centuries, the region was fortified by construction of a large network of earthen and wooden strongholds and ramparts.<ref>A. Kuzev, V. Gyuzelev (eds.) ''Градове и крепости но Дунава и Черно море'', pp. 16–44.</ref> Around the end of the 8th century, widespread building of new stone fortresses and defensive walls began.<ref>A. Kuzev, V. Gyuzelev (eds.), ''Градове и крепости но Дунава и Черно море'', pp. 45-91.</ref> Romanian historians dispute attributing these walls to the Bulgarians, based on their interpretation of the construction system and archaeological evidence.{{Citation needed|date=March 2010}} The Bulgarians also reconstructed some of the ruined Byzantine fortresses (Kaliakra and Silistra in the 8th century, Madara and [[Varna]] in the 9th).<ref>A. Kuzev, V. Gyuzelev (eds.), ''Градове и крепости но Дунава и Черно море'', pp. 179, 257, 294.</ref> According to Barnea, among other historians, during the following three centuries of Bulgarian domination, Byzantines still controlled the Black Sea coast and the mouths of Danube, and for short periods, even some cities.<ref>I. Barnea, Şt.Ştefănescu, ''Bizantini, romani și bulgari la Dunărea de Jos'', p. 11</ref> But Bulgarian archaeologists note that the last Byzantine coins found, which are considered a proof of Byzantine presence, date in [[Kaliakra]] from the time of Emperor [[Justin II]] (565–578),<ref>A. Kuzev, V. Gyuzelev (eds.), ''Градове и крепости но Дунава и Черно море'', p. 257.</ref> in [[Varna]] from the time of Emperor [[Heraclius]] (610–641),<ref>A. Kuzev, V. Gyuzelev (eds.), ''Градове и крепости но Дунава и Черно море'', p. 293.</ref> and in Tomis from [[Constantine IV]]'s rule (668–685).<ref>S. Vaklinov, "Формиране на старобългарската култура VI-XI век", p. 65.</ref>
At the beginning of the 8th century, [[Justinian II]] visited Dobruja to ask Bulgarian Khan [[Tervel]] for military help. [[Omurtag of Bulgaria|Khan Omurtag]] (815–831) built a "glorious home on Danube" and erected a mound in the middle of the distance between Pliska and his new building, according to his inscription kept in [[Holy Forty Martyrs Church, Veliko Tarnovo|SS. Forty Martyrs Church]] in [[Veliko Tarnovo]]. The location of this edifice is unclear; the main theories place it at Silistra or at [[Păcuiul lui Soare]].<ref>{{cite book|first=Veselin|last=Beshevliev|title=Първобългарски надписи|publisher=Bulgarian Academy of Sciences|year=1979|oclc=5310246|location=Sofia|pages=192–200}}</ref> Many early medieval Bulgar stone inscriptions were found in Dobruja, including historical narratives, inventories of armament or buildings, and commemorative texts.<ref>V Beshevliev, "Първобългарски надписи"<!--page missing--></ref> During this period Silistra became an important Bulgarian ecclesiastical centre—an episcopate after 865 and seat of the Bulgarian Patriarch at the end of the 10th century.<ref>A. Kuzev, V. Gyuzelev (eds.), ''Градове и крепости но Дунава и Черно море'', p. 186.</ref> In 895, [[Hungarian prehistory|Magyar]] tribes from [[Budjak]] invaded Dobruja and northeastern Bulgaria. An old Slavic inscription, found at [[Mircea Vodă, Constanţa|Mircea Vodă]], mentions [[Župa|Zhupan]] Dimitri (Дѣимитрѣ жѹпанѣ), a local feudal landlord prominent in the south of the region in 943.<ref>I. Barnea, Şt.Ştefănescu, ''Bizantini, romani şi bulgari la Dunărea de Jos'', p. 71</ref>
=== Return of Byzantine rule and late migrations, Second Bulgarian Empire and Mongol domination === With financial encouragement from the Byzantine emperor, [[Nicephorus II|Nikephoros II Phocas]], [[Sviatoslav I of Kiev]] agreed to assist the Byzantines in their war with the Bulgarians. Sviatoslav defeated the Bulgarians (led by [[Boris II of Bulgaria|Boris II]]) and proceeded to occupy the whole of northern Bulgaria. He occupied Dobruja in 968 and moved the capital of [[Kievan Rus']] to [[Pereyaslavets]], in the north of the region. Sviatoslav refused to turn his Balkan conquests over to the Byzantines, and the parties fell out as a result. So the Byzantines under [[John I Tzimisces]] reconquered Dobruja in 971 and included it in the theme 'Mesopotamia of the West' (Μεσοποταμια της Δυσεον).<ref>{{cite book|author=Leo Diaconus|authorlink=Leo the Deacon|script-title=ru:Лев Диакон. История|url=http://oldru.narod.ru/biblio/ldiakon1.htm|chapter=Книга Девястая|chapterurl=http://oldru.narod.ru/biblio/ldt6_10.htm#04|language=Russian|location=Moskow|publisher=Наука|series=Памятники исторической мысли|year=1988|isbn=978-5-02-008918-1|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060907142609/http://oldru.narod.ru/biblio/ldiakon1.htm|archivedate=2006-09-07|df=}}</ref>
According to some historians, soon after 976<ref>{{cite book|first=Petar|last= Mutafchiev|title=Добруджа, Сборник от студии|chapter=Добруджа в миналото|location=Sofia|year=1947|publisher=Хемус|language=Bulgarian|page=3|oclc=15533292}}</ref> or in 986, the southern part of Dobruja was included in the Bulgarian state then ruled by [[Tsar Samuil of Bulgaria|Samuil]]. The northern part remained under Byzantine rule, being reorganised in an autonomous ''klimata''.<ref>V. Mărculeţ, ''Asupra organizării teritoriilor bizantine de la Dunărea de Jos în secolele X-XII''</ref><ref>{{cite book | last=Madgearu| first =Alexandru| editor1-last=Popescu|editor1-first=Emilian|editor2-first=Teotei|editor2-last=Tudor| chapter =The Church Organization at the Lower Danube, between 971 and 1020 | title =Études byzantines et post-byzantines| volume =IV | page =75 | location=Iași | publisher =Trinitas | year =2001 | chapterurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20091027040832/http://www.geocities.com/amadgearu/church.PDF | isbn=978-973-8179-38-7|accessdate =2007-05-13 }}</ref> Other historians are of the view that Northern Dobruja was reconquered by Bulgarians as well.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Levchenko|first=M.V.|year=1951|title=Ценный источник по вопросу русско-византийских отношений в X веке|journal=Византийский Временник|volume=4|issn=0132-3776|pages=66–68|language=Russian}}</ref> In 1000, a Byzantine army commanded by [[Theodorokanos]] reconquered the whole of Dobruja,<ref>{{cite web |last=Cedrenus |first=Georgius |authorlink=Georgios Kedrenos |chapter=''Σύνοψις Ιστοριών'' (''Compendium Historiarum''), II, s. 452 |script-title=el:Γεωργίου του Κεδρηνού Σύνοψις ιστοριών. Τομ. Β |editor=Migne, J. P. |publisher=Garnier |location=Paris |year=1889 |language=Greek |series=Patrologiae cursus completus v.122 |chapterurl=http://patrologia.ct.aegean.gr/PG_Migne/Georgius%20Cedrenus_PG%20121-122/Compendium%20historiaru1a.pdf#page=464 |oclc=64824669 |url=http://patrologia.ct.aegean.gr/PG_Migne/Georgius%20Cedrenus_PG%20121-122/Compendium%20historiaru1a.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-02-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070710001416/http://patrologia.ct.aegean.gr/PG_Migne/Georgius%20Cedrenus_PG%20121-122/Compendium%20historiaru1a.pdf#page=464 |archivedate=July 10, 2007 |df= }} </ref> organizing the region as the [[Strategia]] of [[Silistra|Dorostolon]] and, after 1020, as ''[[Paristrion]]'' (Paradounavon).
To prevent mounted attacks from the north, the Byzantines constructed three [[Trajan's Wall|ramparts]] from the Black Sea down to the Danube, in the 10th–11th centuries.<ref>I. Barnea, Şt.Ştefănescu, ''Bizantini, romani și bulgari la Dunărea de Jos'', pp. 112–115</ref><ref>A. Rădulescu, I. Bitoleanu, ''Istoria Dobrogei'', pp. 184–185</ref> According to Bulgarian archaeologists and historians, these fortifications may have been built much earlier and were erected by the First Bulgarian Empire in response to the threat of [[Khazars]]' raids.<ref>{{Cite journal | last=Rashev | first=Rasho| title=Землените укрепителни строежи на Долния Дунав (VII–X в.) | version=[[Doctoral thesis|Candidate Dissertation]]. Typewritten | pages=79–81 | year=1977|location=Sofia|language=Bulgarian}}</ref><ref>S. Vaklinov, "Формиране на старобългарската култура VI-XI век", pp. 79–81.</ref>
From the 10th century, Byzantines accepted small groups of [[Pechenegs]] settling in Dobruja.<ref>I. Barnea, Şt.Ştefănescu, ''Bizantini, romani și bulgari la Dunărea de Jos'', pp. 122–123</ref> In the spring of 1036, an invasion of the Pecheneg devastated large parts of the region,<ref>Cedrenus, ''Historiarum compendium'', [http://patrologia.ct.aegean.gr/PG_Migne/Georgius%20Cedrenus_PG%20121-122/Compendium%20historiaru1a.pdf#page=486 II, s. 514–515] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080409154000/http://patrologia.ct.aegean.gr/PG_Migne/Georgius%20Cedrenus_PG%20121-122/Compendium%20historiaru1a.pdf#page=486 |date=April 9, 2008 }}</ref> destroying the forts at [[Capidava]] and [[Ostrov, Constanța|Dervent]], and burning the settlement of [[Dinogeţia]]. In 1046 the Byzantines accepted the Pecheneg under Kegen settling in Paristrion as foederati.<ref>Cedrenus, ''Historiarum compendium'', [http://patrologia.ct.aegean.gr/PG_Migne/Georgius%20Cedrenus_PG%20121-122/Compendium%20historiaru1a.pdf#page=513 II, s. 582–584] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080409154000/http://patrologia.ct.aegean.gr/PG_Migne/Georgius%20Cedrenus_PG%20121-122/Compendium%20historiaru1a.pdf#page=513 |date=April 9, 2008 }}</ref> The Pecheneg dominated the region until 1059, when [[Isaac I Komnenos]] reconquered Dobruja.
In 1064, an invasion by the [[Oghuz Turks]] affected the region. During 1072 to 1074, when Nestor (the new [[strategos]] of Paristrion) was in Dristra, he found that the Pecheneg ruler, Tatrys, was leading a rebellion. In 1091, three autonomous, probably Pecheneg,<ref>Tatos is mentioned as a [[Patzinak]] by a contemporaneous Byzantine source ({{cite book |author=Joannes Zonaras|authorlink=Joannes Zonaras|chapter= Epitome historiarum, lib. 13–18, s. 713|script-title=el:Ιωάννου του Ζωναρά τα ευρισκόμενα πάντα: ιστορικά, κανονικά, δογματικά (μέροςβ΄)|editor=Migne, J.P.|year=1887|location=Paris|language=Greek |series=Patrologiae cursus completus v.135|oclc=38636706|chapterurl=http://patrologia.ct.aegean.gr/PG_Migne/Ioannes%20Zonaras_PG%20134-135/Epitome%20historiarum_.pdf#page=190}}). This opinion is supported by modern historians ({{cite journal|last=Madgearu|first=Alexandru|title=Dunărea în epoca bizantină (secolele X-XII): o frontieră permeabilă|journal=Revista istorică|volume=10|issue=1–2|pages=48–49|url=http://www.geocities.com/amadgearu/dunarea.PDF|format=PDF|accessdate=2007-04-16|language=Romanian|year=1999|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070709235847/http://www.geocities.com/amadgearu/dunarea.PDF|archivedate=2007-07-09}}). They were considered to be Vlach or Russian by some authors. For a survey of these opinions see I. Barnea, Şt.Ştefănescu, ''Bizantini, romani şi bulgari la Dunărea de Jos'', pp. 139–147 {{cite web |url=http://patrologia.ct.aegean.gr/PG_Migne/Ioannes%20Zonaras_PG%20134-135/Epitome%20historiarum_.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-05-16 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070710005520/http://patrologia.ct.aegean.gr/PG_Migne/Ioannes%20Zonaras_PG%20134-135/Epitome%20historiarum_.pdf#page=190 |archivedate=July 10, 2007 |df= }}</ref> rulers were mentioned in the [[Alexiad]]: Tatos (''Τατοῦ'') or Chalis (''χαλῆ''), in the area of [[Silistra|Dristra]] (probably the same person as Tatrys),<ref>I. Barnea, Şt.Ştefănescu, ''Bizantini, romani şi bulgari la Dunărea de Jos'', pp. 136, 141</ref> and Sesthlav (''Σεσθλάβου'') and Satza (''Σατζά'') in the area of [[Vicina (town)|Vicina]].<ref>{{cite book |first=Anna |last=Comnena|authorlink=Anna Komnene|title=The Alexiad|editor=Elizabeth A. Dawes|location=London|publisher=Routledge, Kegan, Paul |year=1928 |url=http://www.fordham.edu/halsall/basis/annacomnena-alexiad00.html |chapter=Book VI, 14 |chapterurl=http://www.fordham.edu/halsall/basis/AnnaComnena-Alexiad06.html|page=164|accessdate=2007-04-28|oclc=67891792}}</ref>[[File:Bulgaria-second half of the 13th century.png|thumb|350px|right|Bulgaria in the second half of the 13th century. The red points show the range of the Ivailo Uprising.]] The [[Cumans]] moved into Dobruja in 1094 and were influential in the region until the advent of the [[Ottoman Empire]].<ref>A. Rădulescu, I. Bitoleanu, ''Istoria Dobrogei'', pp. 192–193</ref> In 1187 the Byzantines lost control of Dobruja to the restored Bulgarian Empire. In 1241, the first [[Tatar confederation|Tatar]] groups, under [[Kadan]], invaded Dobruja starting a century long history of turmoil in the region.<ref name="ID 194">A. Rădulescu, I. Bitoleanu, ''Istoria Dobrogei'', p. 194</ref> Around 1263–64, Byzantine Emperor [[Michael VIII Palaeologus]] gave permission to [[Sultan]] [[Kaykaus II]] to settle in the area with a group of [[Sultanate of Rûm|Seljuk Turks]] from [[Anatolia]].<ref>P. Wittek, ''Yazijioghlu 'Ali on the Christian Turks of the Dobruja'', pp. 640, 648</ref> A missionary [[dervish|Turkish mystic]], [[Sari Saltik|Sarı Saltuk]], was the spiritual leader of this group.<ref>P. Wittek, ''Yazijioghlu 'Ali on the Christian Turks of the Dobruja'', pp. 648, 658</ref> His tomb in [[Babadag]] (which was named after him)<ref>{{Cite book|last=Rezachevici |first=Constantin |title=Găgăuzii |journal=Magazin Istoric |issue=6 |date=May 1997 |url=http://www.itcnet.ro/history/archive/mi1997/current5/mi60.htm |accessdate=2007-04-29 |oclc=50096285 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070126232358/http://www.itcnet.ro/history/archive/mi1997/current5/mi60.htm |archivedate=January 26, 2007 }}</ref> is still a place of pilgrimage for Muslims.<ref>Ив. К. Димитровъ, Прѣселение на селджукски турци въ Добруджа около срѣдата на XIII вѣкъ, стр. 32—33</ref> Arab chronicles of the 13th century mentioned Dobrogea under the name “Şakji” and the Vlachs inhabitants under the names “al-Awalak” and “ulaqut” <ref>Dimitri Korobeinikov, "A broken mirror: the Kipçak world in the thirteenth century", In: ''The Other Europe from the Middle Ages,'' Edited by Florin Curta, Brill 2008, p. 396</ref> In 1265, the Bulgarian Emperor [[Constantine Tikh of Bulgaria|Constantine Tikh Asen]] hired 20,000 Tatars to cross the Danube and attack Byzantine [[Thrace]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Andreev|first1=Yordan|last2=Lalkov|first2=Milcho|title=Българските ханове и царе от хан Кубрат до цар Борис III|location=[[Veliko Tarnovo]] |year=1996|language=Bulgarian |isbn=978-954-427-216-6| publisher=Абагар|page=214}}</ref><ref>Pachymeres, ib., pp. 230-231</ref> On their way back, the Tatars forced most of the Seljuk Turks, including their chief Sarı Saltuk, to resettle in Kipchak (Cumania).<ref>Ив. К. Димитровъ, каз. стат., стр. 33–34</ref><ref>Васил Н. Златарски, ''История на българската държава през срeднитe вeкове. Том III. Второ българско царство. България при Асeневци (1187–1280), стр. 517</ref>
In the second part of the 13th century, the Turkic–Mongolian [[Golden Horde]] Empire continuously raided and plundered Dobruja.<ref>П. Ников, каз. съч., стр. 143</ref> The inability of the Bulgarian authorities to cope with the numerous raids became the main reason for the uprising, led by [[Ivailo of Bulgaria|Ivailo]] (1277–1280), that broke out in eastern Bulgaria.<ref>Васил Н. Златарски, ''История на българската държава през срeднитe вeкове. Том III. Второ българско царство. България при Асeневци (1187–1280), стр. 545-549''</ref> Ivailo's army defeated the Tatars, who were forced to leave the Bulgarian territory; he next outed Constantine Tikh's army, and Ivailo was crowned Emperor of Bulgaria.
The war with the Tatars continued. In 1278, after a new Tatar invasion in Dobruja, Ivailo was forced to retreat to the strong fortress of Silistra, where he withstood a three-month siege.<ref>Y. Andreev, M. Lalkov, ''Българските ханове и царе'', p. 226</ref> In 1280 the Bulgarian nobility, which feared the growing influence of the peasant emperor, organised a coup. Ivailo had to flee to his enemy the Tatar [[Nogai Khan]], who later killed him.<ref>Васил Н. Златарски, ''История на българската държава през срeднитe вeкове. Том III. Второ българско царство. България при Асeневци (1187—1280), стр. 554''</ref> In 1300 [[Toqta]], the new Khan of the Golden Horde, ceded [[Bessarabia]] to Emperor [[Theodore Svetoslav of Bulgaria|Theodore Svetoslav]].<ref>Y. Andreev, M. Lalkov, ''Българските ханове и царе'', p. 247</ref>
[[File:Kaliakra Fortress.jpg|thumb|250px|[[Kaliakra|Kaliakra fortress]], the seat of the autonomous Dobrujan Principality]]
=== Autonomous Dobruja === {{Main|Principality of Karvuna}} In 1325, the [[Ecumenical Patriarch]] nominated Methodius as Metropolitan of Varna and Carvona.<ref>{{cite book|title=Acta et diplomata Graeca medii aevi sacra et profana, vol. I|editor1=Miklosich, Franz |editor2=Müller |location=Vien|publisher=Carolus Gerold|year=1860|chapter=LXIII. 6883—1325 maio-iunio ind. VIII. ''Synodus dirimit sex controversias''|page=135}}</ref> After this date, [[Balik (ruler)|Balik/Balica]]<ref>Names of the rulers of the Principality of Karvuna are given here as spelled in modern Bulgarian and Romanian, respectively.</ref> is mentioned as a local ruler in Southern Dobruja. In 1346, he supported [[John V Palaeologus]] in his [[Byzantine civil war of 1341–1347|dispute]] for the Byzantine throne with [[John VI Cantacuzenus]]. He sent an army corps under his son [[Dobrotitsa|Dobrotitsa/Dobrotici]] and his brother, Theodore, to help the mother of John Palaeologus, Anna of Savoy. For his bravery, Dobrotitsa received the title of ''strategos'' and married the daughter of [[megadux]] [[Alexios Apokaukos|Apokaukos]].<ref>{{cite book |author=Ioannes Cantacuzenus |authorlink=John VI Kantakouzenos |chapter=''Historiae'', II, s. 584–585 |script-title=el:Ιωάννου του Καντακουζηνού τα ευρισκόμενα πάντα: ιστορικά, θεολογικά, απολογητικά, μέρος 1ο |editor=Migne, J.P. |location=Paris |year=1866 |publisher=Apud J.-P. Migne |chapterurl=http://patrologia.ct.aegean.gr/PG_Migne/Ioannes%20Cantacuzenus_PG%20153-154/Historiae.pdf#page=399 |oclc=17356688 |series=Patrologiae cursus completus v.153 |language=Greek |url=http://patrologia.ct.aegean.gr/PG_Migne/Ioannes%20Cantacuzenus_PG%20153-154/Historiae.pdf |accessdate=2007-05-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070710003503/http://patrologia.ct.aegean.gr/PG_Migne/Ioannes%20Cantacuzenus_PG%20153-154/Historiae.pdf#page=399 |archivedate=July 10, 2007 |df= }} </ref> After the reconciliation of the two pretenders, a territorial dispute broke out between the Dobrujan polity and the Byzantine Empire for the port of [[Kıyıköy|Midia]].<ref>{{Cite journal | author = Miller, Timothy S. | title = The History of John Cantacuzenus (Book IV): Text, Translation and Commentary | publisher = Catholic University of America | year = 1975 | url = http://www.deremilitari.org/resources/sources/cantacuzenus.htm | accessdate = 2007-04-28 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070926234529/http://www.deremilitari.org/resources/sources/cantacuzenus.htm | archivedate = 2007-09-26 | df = }}</ref> In 1347, at John V Palaeologus' request, [[Emir]] [[Umur of Aydın|Bahud-din Umur]], [[Bey]] of [[Aydin]], led a naval expedition against Balik, destroying Dobruja's seaports. Balik and Theodore died during the confrontation, and Dobrotitsa became the new ruler.<ref>A. Rădulescu, I. Bitoleanu, ''Istoria Dobrogei'', p. 197</ref> [[File:DobrXIV.png|thumb|left|Principality of Dobrotici/Dobrotitsa during the 1370s]] Between 1352 and 1359, with the collapse of Golden Horde rule in Northern Dobruja, a new state appeared. It was controlled by [[Tatar]] prince [[Demetrius, Prince of the Tatars|Demetrius]], who claimed to be the protector of the river mouths of the Danube.<ref name="DID 351">I. Barnea, Şt.Ştefănescu, ''Bizantini, romani și bulgari la Dunărea de Jos'', p. 351</ref>
In 1357 Dobrotitsa was mentioned as a ''[[Despot (court title)|despot]]'' ruling over a large territory, including the fortresses of [[Varna]], Kozeakos (near [[Obzor]]), and [[Emona (Burgas)|Emona]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Acta et diplomata Graeca medii aevi sacra et profana, vol. I|editor1=Miklosich, Franz |editor2=Müller |location=Vien|publisher=Carolus Gerold|year=1860|chapter=CLXVI. (6865—1357) iunio ind. X. ''Synodus metropolitae Mesembriae restituit duo castella''|page=367}}</ref> In 1366, John V Palaeologus visited Rome and [[Buda]], trying to gather military support for his campaigns. On his return, he was captured at Vidin by [[Ivan Alexander of Bulgaria|Ivan Alexander]], [[Tsar]] of [[Tarnovo]], who believed that the new alliances were directed against his realm. An anti-Ottoman crusade under [[Amadeus VI of Savoy]], supported by the republics of [[Republic of Venice|Venice]] and [[Republic of Genoa|Genoa]], was diverted to free the Byzantine emperor. Dobrotitsa collaborated with the crusaders, and after the allies conquered several Bulgarian forts on the Black Sea, Ivan Alexander freed John and negotiated a peace agreement. Dobrotitsa's role in this conflict brought him numerous political advantages: his daughter married one of John V's sons, Michael, and his principality extended its control over some of the forts lost by the Bulgarians ([[Pomorie|Anchialos]] and [[Nesebar|Mesembria]]).
In 1368, after the death of prince Demetrius, Dobrotitsa was recognised as ruler by [[Mangalia|Pangalia]] and other cities on the right bank of the Danube. In 1369, together with [[Vladislav I of Wallachia]], Dobrotitsa helped Prince [[Ivan Stratsimir of Bulgaria|Stratsimir]] to win back the throne of [[Tsardom of Vidin|Vidin]].
Between 1370 and 1375, allied with Venice, Dobritsia challenged Genoese power in the Black Sea. In 1376, he tried to impose his son-in law, Michael, as Emperor of [[Empire of Trebizond|Trebizond]], but was unsuccessful. Dobrotitsa supported John V Palaeologus against his son [[Andronicus IV Palaeologus]]. In 1379, the Dobrujan fleet participated in the blockade of [[Constantinople]], fighting with the Genoese fleet.
In 1386, Dobrotitsa died and was succeeded by [[Ivanko (despot)|Ivanko/Ioankos]]. That same year he accepted a peace agreement with [[Murad I]] and in 1387 signed a commercial treaty with Genoa. Ivanko was killed in 1388 during the expedition of [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] [[List of Ottoman Grand Viziers|Grand Vizier]] [[Çandarli Ali Pasha]] against [[Tarnovo]] and [[Silistra|Dristra]]. The expedition brought most of the Dobrujan forts under Turkish rule.
=== Wallachian rule ===
In 1388/1389 Dobruja (''Terrae Dobrodicii''—as mentioned in a document from 1390) and Dristra (''Dârstor'') came under the control of [[Mircea cel Bătrân of Wallachia|Mircea the Elder]], ruler of [[Wallachia]], who defeated the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman Grand Vizier]]. [[File:Tara Rumaneasca map.png|thumb|350px|Dobruja (''Terra Dobrotici'') as part of Wallachia under Mircea the Elder]] Ottoman [[Sultan]] [[Bayezid I]] conquered the southern part of the territory in 1393, attacking Mircea one year later, but without success. In the spring of 1395 [[Mircea cel Bătrân of Wallachia|Mircea]] regained the lost Dobrujan territories, with the help of his [[Hungary|Hungarian]] allies.
The Ottomans recaptured Dobruja in 1397 and ruled it to 1404, although in 1401 Mircea strongly defeated an Ottoman army.
The defeat of Sultan Beyezid I by [[Tamerlane]] at [[Battle of Ankara|Ankara]] in 1402 opened a period of anarchy in the Ottoman Empire. Mircea took advantage of it to organise a new anti-Ottoman campaign: in 1403, he occupied the Genoese fort of [[Chilia Veche|Kilia]] at the mouths of the Danube. Thus in 1404, he could impose his authority on Dobruja. In 1416, Mircea supported the revolt against [[Ottoman Dynasty|Sultan]] [[Mehmed I]], led by [[Sheikh Bedreddin]] in the area of Deliorman, in Southern Dobruja.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia | last = İnalcık | first = Halil | authorlink = Halil İnalcık | title = Dobru<u>dj</u>a | encyclopedia = [[Encyclopaedia of Islam]] | volume = II | page = 611 b | publisher = [[Brill Publishers|E. J. Brill]] | location = Leiden |year=1998 |isbn=978-90-04-07026-4}}</ref>
After Mircea's death in 1418, his son [[Michael I of Wallachia|Mihail I]] fought against the amplified Ottoman attacks, eventually being killed in a battle in 1420. That year, the Sultan Mehmed I personally conducted the definitive conquest of Dobruja by the [[Ottoman Empire|Turks]]. [[Wallachia]] kept only the mouths of the Danube, but not for a long duration.
In the late 14th century, German traveller [[Johann Schiltberger]] described these lands as follows:<ref>{{cite book | title = Istorija i civilizacija za 11. klas | last = Delev | first = Petǎr |author2=Valeri Kacunov|author3=Plamen Mitev|author4=Evgenija Kalinova|author5=Iskra Baeva|author6=Bojan Dobrev | chapter = 19. Bǎlgarija pri Car Ivan Aleksandǎr | year = 2006 | language = Bulgarian | publisher = Trud, Sirma }}</ref>
{{quote|I was in three regions, and all three were called Bulgaria. ... The third Bulgaria is there, where the [[Danube]] flows into [[Black Sea|the sea]]. Its capital is called Kaliakra.}}
=== Ottoman rule === [[File:Danube mouths 1867.JPG|thumb|Map of the Danube mouths from 1867 by [[Heinrich Kiepert]]]] Occupied by the Turks in 1420, the region remained under Ottoman control until the late 19th century. Initially, it was organised as an ''u<u>dj</u>'' (border province), included in the [[sanjak]] of Silistra, part of the [[Rumelia|Vilayet of Rumelia]]. Later, under [[Murad II]] or [[Suleiman the Magnificent|Suleiman I]], the sanjak of Silistra and surrounding territories were organised as [[Silistra Province, Ottoman Empire|a separate Vilayet]].<ref>A. Rădulescu, I. Bitoleanu, ''Istoria Dobrogei'', p. 205</ref> In 1555, a revolt led by the "false" (''düzme'') Mustafa, a pretender to the Turkish throne, broke out against Ottoman administration in [[Rumelia]] and rapidly spread to Dobruja, but was repressed by the [[beylerbey]] of [[Nikopol, Bulgaria|Nigbolu]].<ref>A. Rădulescu, I. Bitoleanu, ''Istoria Dobrogei'', p. 249</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=History of the Ottoman Empire and Modern Turkey|last=Shaw|first=Stanford Jay|author2=Ezel Kural Shaw|publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]|year=1977|page=109|volume=1|isbn=978-0-521-29163-7}}</ref>
In 1603 and 1612, the region suffered from the forays of [[Cossack]]s, who burnt down [[Isaccea|Isaķči]] and plundered [[Constanţa|Küstendje]]. The Russian Empire occupied Dobruja several times during the [[Russo-Turkish Wars]] — in 1771–1774, 1790–1791, 1809–1810, 1829 and 1853. The most violent invasion was that of 1829, which resulted in the depopulation of numerous villages and towns. The [[Treaty of Adrianople (1829)|Treaty of Adrianople]] of 1829 ceded the [[Danube Delta]] to the [[Russian Empire]]. However, Russia was forced to return it to the Ottomans in 1856, after the [[Crimean War]]. In 1864 Dobruja was included in the [[Danube Province, Ottoman Empire|vilayet of Tuna]]. [[File:Le port de Kustendje.jpg|thumb|left|300px|The port of [[Constanța|Kustendje]] in 1856. Drawing by Camille Allard]] During Ottoman rule, groups of [[Turkish people|Turk]], [[Arab]] and Tatar peoples settled in the region, the latter especially between 1512 and 1514. During the reign of [[Peter I of Russia]] and [[Catherine the Great]], [[Lipovans]] immigrated to the region of the Danube Delta. After the destruction of [[Zaporozhian Sich]] in 1775, [[Cossacks]] were settled in the area north of Lake Razim by the Turkish authorities (where they founded the [[Danubian Sich]]). They were forced to leave Dobruja in 1828.
In the second part of the nineteenth‑century, [[Ruthenians]] from the [[Austrian Empire]] also settled in the Danube Delta. After the [[Crimean War]], a large number of [[Crimean Tatars|Tatars]] were forcibly driven away from [[Crimea]], immigrating to then-Ottoman Dobruja and settling mainly in the Karasu Valley in the centre of the region and around Bābā Dāgh. In 1864, [[Circassians]] fleeing from the Russian invasion of the [[Caucasus]] were settled in the wooded region near Bābā Dāgh. [[Dobrujan Germans|Germans]] from [[Bessarabia]] also founded colonies in Dobruja between 1840 and 1892. [[File:Dobrogea-Bugeac harta etnica (1861).JPG|thumb|Ethnic map of the Danube mouths from 1861, according to the French geographer Guillaume Lejean. (See the legend '''[[:commons:File:Balkans-ethnic (1861).jpg|here]]''')]] According to Bulgarian historian [[Liubomir Miletich]], most Bulgarians living in Dobruja in 1900 were nineteenth-century settlers or their descendants.<ref>{{cite book|first=Liubomir|last=Miletich|title=Старото българско население в северо-източна България|year=1902|location=Sofia|publisher=Книжовно Дружество|page=6|language=Bulgarian|oclc=67304814}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|first=Liubomir|last=Miletich|title=Südslavische Dialektstudien: das Ostbulgarische|location=Vienna|year=1903|publisher=1903|language=German|oclc=65828513|page=19}}</ref> In 1850, the scholar [[Ion Ionescu de la Brad]], wrote in a study on Dobruja, ordered by the Ottoman government, that Bulgarians came to the region "in the last twenty years or so".<ref>"Les Bulgares sont venus dans la Dobrodja depuis une vingtaine d'années, abandonnant des terres ingrates pour celles bien plus fertiles qu'ils ont trouvée dans ce pays" in {{cite book|title=Excursion agricole dans la plaine de la Dobrodja|last=Jonesco|first=J.|authorlink=Ion Ionescu de la Brad|location=Constantinopole|publisher=Imprimerie du Journal de Constantinopole|year=1850|oclc=251025693|language=French|page=82}}</ref> According to his study, there were 2,285 Bulgarian families (out of 8,194 Christian families) in the region,<ref>{{cite book|title=Annali universali di statistica, economia, pubblica, geografia, storia, viaggi e commercio|author=Lampato, Francesco (ed.)|location=Milano|publisher=Presso la Societa' degli Editori degli Annali Universali delle Scienze e dell'Industria|year=1851|language=Italian|page=211}}</ref> 1,194 of them in Northern Dobruja.<ref name="Dmono 177">{{cite book|title=Dobrogea. Gurile Dunării şi Insula Şerpilor. Schiţă monografică|last=Seişanu|first=Romulus|location=Bucureşti|publisher=Tipografia ziarului "Universul"|year=1928|language=Romanian|page=177}}</ref> Liubomir Miletich puts the number of Bulgarian families in Northern Dobruja in the same year at 2,097.<ref>L. Miletich, ''Старото българско население в северо-източна България'', pp. 169–170</ref> According to the statistics of the [[Bulgarian Exarchate]], before 1877 there were 9,324 Bulgarian families out of a total 12,364 Christian families in the Northern Dobruja.<ref name="IstBg7 412">{{cite book|last1=Kosev|first1=D.|last2=Hristov|first2=Hr.|last3=Todorov|first3=N.|last4=Angelov|first4=D.|title=Възстановяване и утвърждаване на българската държава. Националноосвободителни борби 1878-1903|series=История на България|volume=7|publisher=Издателство на Българската академия на науките|location=Sofia|year=1991|oclc=63809870|language=Bulgarian|page=412}}</ref>{{Verify source|date=September 2007}} According to Russian [[Knyaz#Russia|knyaz]] Vladimir Cherkassky, chief of the Provisional Russian government in Bulgaria in 1877-1878, the Bulgarian population in Dobruja was larger than the Romanian one.<ref name="IstBg7 412"/> However, count Shuvalov, the Russian representative to the [[Congress of Berlin]], stated that Romania deserved Dobruja "more than anybody else, because of its population".<ref>A. Rădulescu, I. Bitoleanu, ''Istoria Dobrogei'', p. 337</ref> In 1878, the statistics of the Russian governor of Dobruja, Bieloserkovitsch, showed a number of 4,750 Bulgarian "family chiefs" (out of 14,612 Christian family chiefs) in the northern half of the region.<ref name="Dmono 177"/>
The Christian religious organisation of the region was put under the authority of the [[Bulgarian Exarchate|Bulgarian Orthodox Church]] by a [[firman (decree)|firman]] of the [[Ottoman Dynasty|Sultan]], promulgated on February 28, 1870.<ref>Kosev et al., ''Възстановяване и утвърждаване на българската държава'', pp. 460–461</ref> However, the ethnic Greeks and most Romanians in Northern Dobruja remained under the authority of the [[Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople|Greek]] Archdiocese of [[Tulcea|Tulča]] (founded in 1829).<ref>{{cite book|author=Baron d'Hogguer|title=Informaţiuni asupra Dobrogei. Starea eĭ de astăḍi. Resursele şi viitorul ei|date=February 1879|publisher=Editura Librăriei SOCEC|location=Bucureşci|language=Romanian}}</ref><ref>A. Rădulescu, I. Bitoleanu, ''Istoria Dobrogei'', pp. 322–323</ref>
===After 1878=== [[File:Trecerea dunarii 1878.jpeg|thumb|left|Romanian troops triumphantly cross the Danube into Northern Dobruja, in a colourful patriotic lithograph, 1878]] [[File:Histdob.png|220px|right|thumb|Dobruja after 1878.]] After the 1878 war, the [[Treaty of San Stefano]] awarded Dobruja to [[Russian Empire|Russia]] and the newly established [[Principality of Bulgaria]]. The northern portion, held by Russia, was ceded to Romania in exchange for Russia obtaining territories in [[Southern Bessarabia]], thereby securing a direct access to the mouths of the [[Danube]]. In Northern Dobruja, Romanians were the plurality. The population included a Bulgarian ethnic enclave in the northeast (around [[Babadag]]), as well as an important Muslim community (mostly Turks and Tatars) scattered around the region.
The southern portion, held by Bulgaria, was reduced the same year by the [[Treaty of Berlin (1878)|Treaty of Berlin]]. At the advice of the French envoy, a strip of land extended inland from the port of [[Mangalia]] (shown orange on the map) was ceded to Romania, since its southwestern corner contained a compact area of ethnic Romanians. The town of [[Silistra]], located at the areas' most southwestern point, remained Bulgarian due to its large Bulgarian population. Romania subsequently tried to occupy the town as well, but in 1879 a new international commission allowed Romania to occupy only the fort ''Arab Tabia'', which overlooked Silistra, but not the town itself.
[[File:Dobroudja_(carte_ethnographique).JPG|thumb|200px|Ethnic groups in Dobruja around 1918]] At the beginning of the [[Russo-Turkish War, 1877–1878|Russo-Turkish War of 1877–1878]], most of Dobruja's population was composed of ethnic Turks, Bulgarians and Tatars. During the war, a large part of the Muslim population was evacuated to Bulgaria and Turkey.<ref>A. Rădulescu, I. Bitoleanu, ''Istoria Dobrogei'', p. 333</ref> After 1878, the Romanian government encouraged Romanians from other regions to settle in Northern Dobruja and accepted the return of some Muslim population displaced by the war.<ref>A. Rădulescu, I. Bitoleanu, ''Istoria Dobrogei'', pp. 358–360</ref>
According to Bulgarian historians, after 1878 the Romanian church authorities took control over all local churches, with the exception of two in the towns of Tulcea and Constanţa, which managed to retain use of their Bulgarian Slavonic liturgy.<ref>Kosev et al., ''Възстановяване и утвърждаване на българската държава'' p. 416</ref> Between 1879 and 1900, Bulgarians built 15 new churches in Northern Dobruja.<ref>A. Rădulescu, I. Bitoleanu, ''Istoria Dobrogei'', p. 365</ref> After 1880, [[Italians]] from [[Friuli]] and [[Veneto]] settled in Greci, Cataloi and [[Măcin]] in Northern Dobruja. Most of them worked in the granite quarries in the [[Măcin Mountains]], while some became farmers.<ref>{{Cite journal |journal=[[România Liberă]]|first=Alexandru |last=Mihalcea |title=150 de ani de istorie comuna. Italienii din Dobrogea -mica Italie a unor mesteri mari|date=2005-01-21|url=http://www.alef-fvg.it/emigrazione/approfondimenti/romania2005.htm |accessdate=2007-04-29|language=Romanian |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060607103203/http://www.alef-fvg.it/emigrazione/approfondimenti/romania2005.htm |archivedate = June 7, 2006}}</ref> The Bulgarian authorities encouraged the settling of ethnic Bulgarians in the territory of Southern Dobruja.<ref>A. Rădulescu, I. Bitoleanu, ''Istoria Dobrogei'', pp. 363-364, 381</ref>
In May 1913, the [[Great Powers]] awarded Silistra and the area in a 3 km radius around it to Romania, at the [[Saint Petersburg]] Conference. In August 1913, after the [[Second Balkan War]], Bulgaria lost [[Southern Dobruja]] (''Cadrilater'') to Romania (See [[Treaty of Bucharest, 1913]]). With Romania's entry in [[World War I]] on the side of France and Russia, the [[Central Powers]] occupied all of Dobruja and gave the Cadrilater, as well as the southern portion of Northern Dobruja, to Bulgaria in the [[Treaty of Bucharest, 1918|Treaty of Bucharest]] of 1918. This situation lasted for a short period. As the [[Allies of World War I|Allied Powers]] emerged victorious at the end of the war, Romania regained the lost territories in the [[Treaty of Neuilly]] of 1919. Between 1926 and 1938, about 30,000 [[Aromanians]] from Bulgaria, [[Macedonia (region)|Macedonia]], and Greece, were resettled in Southern Dobruja.
In 1923 the [[Internal Dobrujan Revolutionary Organisation]] (IDRO), a Bulgarian nationalist organisation, was established. Active in Southern Dobruja under different forms until 1940, the IDRO detachments fought against the widespread brigandage in the region,{{Citation needed|date=December 2007}} as well as the Romanian administration. Thus, while considered "a terrorist organisation" by the Romanian authorities, the IDRO was regarded by ethnic Bulgarians as a liberation movement. In 1925, part of the Bulgarian revolutionary committees formed the Dobrujan Revolutionary Organisation (DRO), which later became subordinated to the [[Communist Party of Romania]]. In contrast with the IDRO, which fought for the inclusion of the region in the Bulgarian state, the DRO requested the independence of Dobruja and its inclusion in a projected [[Balkan federalism|Federative Republic of the Balkans]].<ref>A. Rădulescu, I. Bitoleanu, ''Istoria Dobrogei'', p. 430</ref> The means used by DRO to attain its goals were also more peaceful.
During [[World War II]], Bulgaria regained Southern Dobruja in the September 1940 [[Axis Powers|Axis]]-sponsored [[Treaty of Craiova]], despite Romanian negotiators' insistence that [[Balchik]] and other towns should remain in Romania. As part of the treaty, the [[Romanians|Romanian]] inhabitants (Aromanian [[refugee]]-[[settler]]s, settlers from other regions of Romania and the Romanians indigenous to the region) were forced to leave the regained territory, while the Bulgarian minority in the north was expelled to go to Bulgaria in a [[population exchange]]. The post-war [[Paris Peace Treaties, 1947|Paris Peace Treaties]] of 1947 reaffirmed the 1940 border.
In 1948 and again in 1961–1962, Bulgaria proposed a border rectification in the area of Silistra, consisting mainly in the transfer of a Romanian territory containing the water source of that city. Romania made an alternative proposal that did not involve a territorial change and, ultimately, no rectification took place.<ref>{{Cite journal |journal=[[Ziua]] de Constanţa|first=Mariana |last=Cojoc|author2=Tiță, Magdalena |title=Proiecții teritoriale bulgare|date=2006-09-06|url=http://www.ziuaconstanta.ro/rubrici/documentar/proiectii-teritoriale-bulgare-la-dunare-si-marea-neagra.html|accessdate=2007-02-15|language=Romanian}}</ref>
In Romania, 14 November is a holiday observed as [[Public holidays in Romania|Dobrogea Day]].<ref>[http://www.ziuaconstanta.ro/diverse/stiri-calde/a-fost-promulgata-legea-ce-se-face-de-ziua-dobrogei-567581.html Președintele Iohannis a promulgat legea prin care data de 14 noiembrie este declarată Ziua Dobrogei] {{Ro icon}}</ref>

The total population was 309,151.
== Area, population and cities ==
The entire region of Dobruja has an area of 23,100 km<sup>2</sup> and a population of around 1.2 million, of which just over two-thirds of the former and nearly three-quarters of the latter lie in the Romanian part.

Major cities are [[Constanța]], [[Tulcea]], [[Medgidia]] and [[Mangalia]] in Romania, and [[Dobrich]] and [[Silistra]] in Bulgaria.
