{{Infobox mountain | name = Teckberg | photo = Teckberg.jpg | photo_caption = | elevation_m = 775 | elevation_ref = | prominence_m = | prominence_ref = | map = Germany Baden-Württemberg | range_coordinates = | location = [[Baden-Württemberg]], [[Germany]] | range = | coordinates = {{coord|48|35|17|N|9|28|14|E|type:mountain_region:DE-BW_scale:100000_source:kolossus-dewiki|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | coordinates_ref = | type = | first_ascent = | easiest_route = }} '''Teckberg''' is a mountain at ''[[Esslingen (district)|Landkreis Esslingen]]'' in [[Baden-Württemberg]], Germany, with an elevation of 775 metres.{{Höhe|775.0|DE-NHN|link=true}}{{GeoQuelle|DE|BFN-Karten}} Situated on top is castle [[Teck]].
== Geography ==
The Teckberg jumps from [[Swabian Jura]] edge from about 3 km towards the north front and overlooks the Albvorland to 350 m, the [[Lauter (Neckar)]] valley to 400 m. He is flanked of the approximately 602 m high foothills Hörnle and [[Hohenbol]] north and northwest. Both Foothills include smokestacks of the Swabian volcano. North below the Hörnle is the glider area Teck (between [[Dettingen unter Teck]] and [[Bissingen an der Teck]]). The slope of the Teckberg formed by the Yellow Rock, a Schwammriff the Jura sea of bright lime. Under the "Gelber Fels", is the 31 m long and 45 m high Veronikahöhle, which is connected through columns with Verena-Beutlins-Loch. East of the Gelber Fels (Yellow Rock) three grave mounds indicate from the [[Hallstatt period]] (800-400 BC) the early settlement of the Teckberg. Under the castle Teck is the 35 m long and 9 m high fabled Sibyllenloch, on the other side the 22 m long Sibyllenhöhle. It was only in 1937 discovered during construction work and was explored in 1977. During excavations in Sibyllenloch 1898/99 over 2,000 skeletal remains of cave bear, cave lion, cave hyena and wild horse were found. So many conclusions about the glacial fauna could be drawn.
==Nature Reserve== With regulation of the Regierungspräsidium Stuttgart from 9 November 1999, the entire Teckberg with an area of 386.0 hectares was reported as nature reserve. It was managed to preserve and promote an unusually varied cultural landscape with wet and dry meadows, orchards, hedges, forest fringes, alleys, groves, solitary trees, rocks, caves, springs and rare natural forest communities. These habitats provide a quality habitat for a variety of partly endangered plant and animal species. In the versatile natural area botanists could show 464 different plant species.
==Literature== (in German) *Wolfgang Roser, Jürgen Mauch: ''Der Schwäbische Vulkan.'' GO Druck-Media-Verlag, [[Kirchheim unter Teck]] 2003, {{ISBN|3-925589-29-5}}. *Konrad Theiss: ''Der Kreis Esslingen.'' Theiss, Stuttgart 1978, {{ISBN|3-8062-0171-4}}. *''Naturschutzgebiet Teck'', hrsg. von der Landesanstalt für Umweltschutz Baden-Württemberg (LfU). Verlag Regionalkultur, Ubstadt-Weiher 2000. {{ISBN|978-3-89735-142-4}}. * Reinhard Wolf, Ulrike Kreh (Hrsg.): ''Die Naturschutzgebiete im Regierungsbezirk Stuttgart''. Thorbecke, Ostfildern 2007, {{ISBN|978-3-7995-5176-2}}, S. 492–495
[[Category:Mountains and hills of Baden-Württemberg]] [[Category:Mountains and hills of the Swabian Jura]] [[Category:Mountains under 1000 metres]] [[Category:Protected areas of Europe]]

{{Infobox country telephone plan | country = Israel | country_link = Israel | continent = Asia | map_image = Israel (orthographic projection) new.svg | map_caption = | map_size = 200px | map_alt = | country_calling_code = +972 | international_prefix = 00 or 01x | trunk_prefix = 0 | truz k_prefix = 0 | regulator = [[Ministry of Communications (Israel)|Israeli Ministry of Communications]] | plan_membership = | nsn_length = 8 or 9 (landline)
10 (mobile) | dial_plan_type = closed | number_format = (0A) XXX-XXXX (landline)
05N-XXX-XXXX (mobile) | codes_list = }} '''Telephone numbers in Israel''' consist of an area code and a subscriber number. The [[Telephone numbering plan|dial plan type]] in Israel is closed, and "0" is the internal [[Trunk prefix]] in Israel. Israel's [[List of country calling codes|country calling code]] is +972. When dialing an Israeli number from inside of [[Israel]], the format is :
"0 - Area/network operator code (A/N) - subscriber number (X)" When dialing an Israeli number from outside Israel, the format is :
"+972 - Area/network operator code (A/N) - subscriber number (X)" The Israeli telecommunication infrastructure is including the [[Telephone numbers in the Palestinian territories|Palestinian telecommunication system]]. ==History== In 1965, many Israeli phone numbers had 6 digits, but some had 5, according to the Tel-Aviv-area phone book. http://genealogyindexer.org/view/1965Israel/1965Israel%20-%200196.pdf There were ten area codes at that time: 02 Jerusalem, Bet Shemesh; 03 Tel Aviv, Petah Tikva, Rehovot, Ashdod; 04 Haifa and western Galilee; 051 Ashkelon; 053 Netanya; 057 Beersheva and most of the Negev; 059 Eilat; 065 Afula, Nazareth; 063 Hadera, Zichron Yaakov; and 067 Tiberias, Zefat and eastern Galilee. http://genealogyindexer.org/view/1965Israel/1965Israel%20-%200005.pdf As recently as the 1990s, most telephone numbers in Israel had 6 digits (without area code digit). Currently there are 5 geographic area codes and 2 more non-geographic area codes, and numbers has 7 or 8 digits (without area code digit). With the influence of [[VoIP]] long distance was deregulated in Israel. According to the Israel Ministry of Communication a VoIP number may be [[local number portability|ported]] to a landline carrier and vice versa providing the option to have, say, a northern number in the south of the country. Numbers may not be ported, say, from the north to the south of the country on the same kind of line (e.g., VoIP to VoIP or landline to landline). [[Mobile number portability]] was introduced in late 2007. ==Structure and format== The format for calls to landlines within the same area code is XXX-XXXX (7 digits subscriber number). For calls to a landline outside the local area, the area code is prefixed and the format becomes (0A) XXX-XXXX for calls to landlines, where "0A" is the area code. The format for calls to cellular mobile phones is 05N-XXX-XXXX, where "05N" is the mobile operator indicator. The format for calls to VoIP lines is 07N-XXX-XXXX, where "07N" is the VoIP operator indicator. When calling from outside of Israel, the leading "0" in area codes is not dialed, and the format is +972-A-XXX-XXXX for calls to landlines, +972-5N-XXX-XXXX for calls to mobile lines, +972-7N-XXX-XXXX for calls to VoIP lines. {| class="wikitable" style="margin-left: 1.5em;" |- ! scope="col" | Prefix ! scope="col" | Service type ! scope="col" | Local format ! scope="col" | International format |- ! scope="row" |'''00''', '''01x''' | International call prefix (from Israel to other countries) | 00 or 01x | |- ! scope="row" |'''02''', '''03''', '''04''', '''08''', '''09''' | Geographic area codes | (0A) XXX-XXXX | +972 A XXX-XXXX |- ! scope="row" |'''05''' | Area code for cellular and mobile devices | 05N XXX-XXXX | +972 5N XXX-XXXX |- ! scope="row" |'''07''' | Non-Geographic area code for landline, VoIP and VoC services | 07N XXX-XXXX | +972 7N XXX-XXXX |- ! scope="row" |'''10''', '''11''', '''12''' | Short codes for emergency services | 10X or 11X or 12XX | Not available from abroadHospital emergency services available in +972 1255-XXX. Other emergency services available from abroad by its full number (full numbers can be found in the Internet). |- ! scope="row" |'''151''' | Voice mail | 151-X(X) XXX-XXXX | +972 151-X(X) XXX-XXXX |- ! scope="row" |'''153''' | Fax box | 153-X(X) XXX-XXXX | +972 153-X(X) XXX-XXXX |- ! scope="row" |'''1599''' | Business Toll | 1 599 XXX-XXX | +972 1599 XXX-XXX |- ! scope="row" |'''1700''' | Business Toll | 1 700 XXX-XXX | +972 1700 XXX-XXXNot available from most countries outside Israel |- ! scope="row" |'''180X''' | Toll free | 1 80X XXX-XXX | +972 180X XXX-XXXNot available from most countries outside Israel |- ! scope="row" |'''19XX''' | Premium rate | 1 9XX XXX-XXX | Not available from abroad |} ==International call prefix== For calling from Israel to another country: choose operator, and dial its international access code, then dial destination country code and then the rest of the local number. *'''00''' or '''+''' – short code (only registered customers) *'''012''' – [[012smile]] service *'''013''' – [[013 NetVision]] service *'''014''' – [[Bezeq International]] service *'''015''' – Hallo 015 service *'''016''' – [[Golan Telecom]] service *'''017''' – [[Hot Mobile]] service *'''018''' – Xfone service *'''019''' – [[019 Telzar]] service ==Area codes== Due to mobile number portability, a mobile phone with a prefix of one provider can be associated with a different provider. ===Geographic area codes=== [[File:Israel dialing codes.svg|thumb|Geographic area codes of Israel]] When dialing within one of the geographical area codes (2, 3, 4, 8, 9) the prefix can be dropped (so instead of dialing (0A)XXX-XXXX you can dial XXX-XXXX). {| class="wikitable" align="center" |- ! scope="col" | Local Format ! scope="col" | International format ! scope="col" | Description |- | ('''02''') XXX-XXXX | +972 '''2''' XXX-XXXX | [[Jerusalem District]] area code |- | ('''03''') XXX-XXXX | +972 '''3''' XXX-XXXX | [[Tel Aviv District]] & [[Central District (Israel)|Central District]] area code |- | ('''04''') XXX-XXXX | +972 '''4''' XXX-XXXX | [[Haifa District]] & [[Northern District (Israel)|Northern District]] area code |- | ('''08''') XXX-XXXX | +972 '''8''' XXX-XXXX | [[Shephelah|Lowland]] & [[Southern District (Israel)|Southern District]] area code |- | ('''09''') XXX-XXXX | +972 '''9''' XXX-XXXX | [[Sharon, Israel|Sharon]] area code |} * In the geographic area codes, first digits of the local number are identifying service operator: {| class="wikitable" align="center" |- ! scope="col" | Local Format ! scope="col" | International format ! scope="col" | Operator |- | (0A) '''2'''XX-XXXX | +972 A '''2'''XX-XXXX | [[Paltel]] (In the [[Palestinian Territories]]) |- | (0A) '''30'''X-XXXX

Changed to 053 in November 2014. |- | '''054''' XXX-XXXX | +972 '''54''' XXX-XXXX | [[Partner Communications Company|Partner]] (also operates [[012smile|012mobile]]{{cite web|title=אודות 012 סמייל|url=https://www.012mobile.co.il/About|website=www.012mobile.co.il|accessdate=16 January 2017}}) |- | '''055''' XXX-XXXX | +972 '''55''' XXX-XXXX | ''Mobile virtual network operators (MVNO's)'' |- | '''055 2'''XX-XXXX | +972 '''55 2'''XX-XXXX | [[Cellcom (Israel)|Cellcom]] ''(Formerly Home Cellular)'' |- | '''055 3'''XX-XXXX | +972 '''55 3'''XX-XXXX | Free Telecom ''(Inoperative)'' |- | '''055 4'''XX-XXXX | +972 '''55 4'''XX-XXXX | Cellran (Tadiran) ''(Inoperative)'' |- | '''055 5'''XX-XXXX | +972 '''55 5'''XX-XXXX | Sipme \ Gali Phone ''(Inoperative)'' |- | '''055 6'''XX-XXXX | +972 '''55 6'''XX-XXXX | [[Rami Levy Communications|Rami Levy]] |- | '''055 7'''XX-XXXX | +972 '''55 7'''XX-XXXX | Cellact |- | '''055 7'''XX-XXXX | +972 '''55 7'''XX-XXXX | Bynet Businesses ''(Inoperative)'' |- | '''055 8'''XX-XXXX | +972 '''55 8'''XX-XXXX | [[Pelephone]] ''(Formerly YouPhone)'' |- | '''055 9'''XX-XXXX | +972 '''55 9'''XX-XXXX | 019 Mobile (019 Telzar) |- | '''056''' XXX-XXXX | +972 '''56''' XXX-XXXX | [[Wataniya Mobile]] (in the [[Palestinian territories]]) |- | '''058''' XXX-XXXX | +972 '''58''' XXX-XXXX | [[Golan Telecom]] |- | '''059''' XXX-XXXX | +972 '''59''' XXX-XXXX | [[Paltel|Jawwal]] (in the [[Palestinian territories]]) |} ===Non-geographic nationwide area code 07 === Non-geographic nationwide area code can be used by Landline and VoIP operators. {| class="wikitable" align="center" |- ! scope="col" | Local Format ! scope="col" | International format ! scope="col" | Operator |- | '''071 8'''XX-XXXX | +972 '''71 8'''XX-XXXX | Xfone ''(Inoperative)'' |- | '''072 2'''XX-XXXX

'''073 3'''XX-XXXX | +972 '''73 2'''XX-XXXX
+972 '''73 3'''XX-XXXX | [[Cellcom (Israel)|Cellcom]] |- | '''073 7'''XX-XXXX | +972 '''73 7'''XX-XXXX | Veidan |- | '''074 7'''XX-XXXX | +972 '''74 7'''XX-XXXX | [[Partner Communications Company|Partner]] |- | '''076 5'''XX-XXXX | +972 '''76 5'''XX-XXXX | [[Bezeq International]] |- | '''076 8'''XX-XXXX | +972 '''76 8'''XX-XXXX | [[Bezeq]] |- | '''077''' XXX-XXXX | +972 '''77''' XXX-XXXX | [[Hot (Israel)|Hot]] ([[Altice (company)|Altice]]) |- | '''078 2'''XX-XXXX | +972 '''78 2'''XX-XXXX | [[Golan Telecom]] ''(Inoperative)'' |- | '''079 2'''XX-XXXX | +972 '''79 2'''XX-XXXX | Free Telecom ''(Inoperative)'' |- | '''079 3'''XX-XXXX | +972 '''79 3'''XX-XXXX | Bynet Businesses ''(Inoperative)'' |- | '''079 5'''XX-XXXX | +972 '''79 5'''XX-XXXX | Hallo 015 |- | '''079 7'''XX-XXXX | +972 '''79 7'''XX-XXXX | Cellact |- | '''079 9'''XX-XXXX | +972 '''79 9'''XX-XXXX | 019 Telzar |} ==Special numbers== Special numbers include emergency and aid services, along with technical support and other provider services:[https://www.b144.co.il/EmergencyNo.aspx Emergency numbers] '''100''' - [[Israeli police|Police]] '''101''' - [[Magen David Adom|Ambulance Service]] '''102''' - [[Israel Fire and Rescue Services|Fire Fighters]] '''103''' - [[Israel Electric Corporation|Electric Corporation]] '''104''' - [[Home Front Command]] (Information about how to act in war and earthquake) '''106''' - Municipal Call Center <in '''most''' cities> '''107''' - Municipal Call Center <in some cities> '''108''' - Municipal Call Center <in some cities> '''109''' - Municipal Call Center <in some cities> '''110''' - [[Israeli police|Police]] information service '''118''' - [[Ministry of Social Affairs]] emergency service '''1201''' - Mental health first aid '''1255 XXX''' - Hospital Information Center <only in times of emergency> '''*XXXX''' - (Star and 4 digits) Speed dial service '''1234''' - Bezeq-Card service (Bezeq lines only) '''1455''' - [[Speaking clock]] - Time and date in Israel and around the world '''142''' - [[Collect call|Collect Call]] '''144''' - Telephone Listings Information '''166''' - Bezeq technical support '''199''' - Bezeq customer service '''164''' - Bezeq business customer service '''1 599 XXX XXX''' - [[Business Toll]] '''1 700 XXX XXX''' - Business Toll '''1 80X XXX XXX''' - [[Toll Free]] '''1 90X XXX XXX''' - Premium ==Kosher numbers== Kosher phones and networks are essentially phones with [[Haredi]] [[rabbinical]] approval that can be used for communication without entertainment functionality or connectivity. This is a line that has a pre-defined prefix and it is blocked to content that Haredi activists feel is not appropriate for their community. Such blocking includes cellular internet access, chat rooms, [[SMS]], etc. This does not mean that other phones are not [[kosher]] according to Jewish law, as evidenced by the fact that a very large number - if not the majority - of observant [[Orthodox Judaism|Orthodox Jews]] worldwide do not restrict themselves to "kosher" phones; rather the description "kosher" phones is a loose one, implying an added level of stringency accepted by some communities. The companies who provides "kosher numbers" allocated exclusive ranges for those lines, which are: +972 '''(A) 80'''X-XXXX - [[Bezeq]] (When A = 2,3,4,8,9) +972 '''50 41'''X-XXXX - [[Pelephone]] +972 '''52 71'''X-XXXX - [[Cellcom (Israel)|Cellcom]], second range +972 '''52 76'''X-XXXX - [[Cellcom (Israel)|Cellcom]], first range +972 '''53 31'''X-XXXX - [[Hot Mobile]] +972 '''54 84'''X-XXXX - [[Partner Communications Company|Partner]], first range +972 '''54 85'''X-XXXX - [[Partner Communications Company|Partner]], second range +972 '''58 32'''X-XXXX - [[Golan Telecom]] +972 '''55 67'''X-XXXX - [[Rami Levy Communications|Rami Levy]] +972 '''55 71'''X-XXXX - Cellact +972 '''55 98'''X-XXXX - 019 Telzar +972 '''72 29'''X-XXXX - [[Partner Communications Company|Partner]] ([[012smile]]) +972 '''73 724'''-XXXX - Veidan ==See also== *[[Telephone numbers in the Palestinian territories]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.moc.gov.il/130-en/MOC.aspx Israel Ministry of Communication] *[http://www.moc.gov.il/sip_storage/FILES/3/383.pdf Presentation of E.164 National Numbering For Country Code 972 (Israel), Update August 2007, Israel Ministry of Communication] *[http://www.moc.gov.il/sip_storage/FILES/7/167.pdf Israel Ministry of Communications numbering program] {{he icon}} *[http://www.moc.gov.il/sip_storage/FILES/8/2238.pdf Shortened business numbers] (star numbers) at the Israel Ministry of Communications {{he icon}} *[http://www.moc.gov.il/sip_storage/FILES/7/3947.pdf Change of 057 prefix to 053] {{he icon}} {{Telephone numbers in Asia}} [[Category:Telephone numbers by country|Israel]] [[Category:Telecommunications in Israel]] [[Category:Israel communications-related lists]]

[[image:Almere - Groene Kathedraal.jpg|thumb|The Green Cathedral, by [[Marinus Boezem]]. (July 2009)]] [[File:GOPR0061.MP4 000124020.jpg|thumb|Aerial view]]
'''The Green Cathedral''' or '''De Groene Kathedraal''' located near [[Almere]] Netherlands, is an artistic planting of [[Lombardy poplar]]s (''Populus nigra italica'') that mimics the size and shape of the [[Cathedral of Notre-Dame, Reims]], France. The Green Cathedral is {{convert|150|m|ft|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|75|m|ft|abbr=on}} wide, and the mature poplar trees are approximately {{convert|30|m|ft|abbr=on}} tall.
==History== The work was planted by Marinus Boezem (b. 1934) on April 16, 1987, in Southern [[Flevoland]]. The land art project was installed on [[polder]] land. 178 trees were planted on a knoll, a half-metre above the surrounding area. Over the following years, some trees were replaced due to deer damage, and stone was laid in the floor to echo the cross ribs and support beams of the cathedral.
==Current status== Now mature, the cathedral has become a location for weddings, funerals, meetings and religious services of all kinds.<ref>Reames, Richard. Arborsculpture Solutions for a Small Planet, p. 121</ref> Nearby, a clearing has been made in a young beech forest so that the open space is in the shape of the same cathedral. Boezem suggests, as the poplars decline, the beech trees around the clearing will grow to create the church once more thus ensuring a cyclical evolution of growth, decline and growth.
==References== {{coord|52.323157|5.318778|type:landmark_source:openstreetmap}} <references/>
{{DEFAULTSORT:Green Cathedral}} [[Category:Geography of Flevoland]] [[Category:Land art]] [[Category:1987 establishments in the Netherlands]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Flevoland]] [[Category:Almere]]
{{Flevoland-geo-stub}}

The following is a [[:Category:City timelines|timeline]] of the [[History of Lagos|history]] of the metropolis of [[Lagos]], [[Nigeria]]. {{Dynamic list}} {{TOC right}}
==Prior to 19th century== {{History of Nigeria}}
* 1472 - Ruy de Sequeira of [[Portugal]] names area "Lago de Curamo." * 1600 - [[Ashipa]] becomes [[Oba of Lagos|Oba]]. * 1630 ** King [[Ado (Lagos Oba)|Ado]] in power. ** [[Iga Idunganran]] built (approximate date). * 1669 - King [[Gabaro]] in power. * 1704 - King [[Akinsemoyin]] in power. * 1749 ** [[Eletu Kekere]] becomes Oba. ** King [[Ologun Kutere]] in power. * 1775 - [[Adele Ajosun]] becomes Oba. * 1780 - [[Osinlokun|Eshilokun]] becomes Oba.
==19th century== [[Image:1898 Lagos Nigeria map byJohnston BostonPublicLibrary m0612007.png|thumb|right|Detail of 1898 map showing Lagos, Nigeria]]
* 1829 - Oba [[Idewu Ojulari]] in power. * 1837 - Oba [[Oluwole]] in power. * 1841 - [[Akitoye]] becomes Oba.<ref name="Falola2009">{{cite book|author1=[[Toyin Falola]]|author2=Ann Genova|title=Historical Dictionary of Nigeria |year= 2009|publisher=[[Scarecrow Press]] |isbn=978-0-8108-6316-3 }}</ref> * 1845 - Oba [[Kosoko]] in power.<ref name="Falola2009" /> * 1851 - [[Reduction of Lagos|British bombardment of Lagos]].{{sfn|Britannica|1890}}{{sfn|Smith|1979}} * 1852 - British [[Treaty Between Great Britain and Lagos, 1 January 1852|consulate established]].{{sfn|Smith|1979}} * 1853 - King [[Dosunmu]] in power. *1859- The [[CMS Grammar School, Lagos|CMS Grammar School]] in Bariga, a suburb of Lagos in Lagos State, is the oldest secondary school in Nigeria, founded on 6 June 1859 by the Church Missionary Society * 1860 - [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Lagos|Catholic church]] established.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.catholicdioceseoyo.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=80:historical-hints&catid=36:articles |title=Historical Hints: Dotted Events in Nigerian History |publisher=Catholic Diocese of Oyo |accessdate=17 June 2012 }}</ref> * 1861 - Lagos [[Lagos Treaty of Cession|annexed by the British]].{{sfn|Britannica|1890}}<ref name="Falola2009chron">{{cite book|author1=Toyin Falola|author2=Ann Genova|title=Historical Dictionary of Nigeria |year= 2009|publisher=Scarecrow Press |isbn=978-0-8108-6316-3 |chapter=Chronology |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rdDKeMEwPdMC }}</ref> * 1862 - Lagos becomes a [[Lagos Colony|British colony]]. * 1866 - Population: 25,083. * 1878 - [[Methodist Boys High School|Methodist Boys' High School]] founded. * 1881 - Population: 37,452. * 1885 - Oba [[Oyekan I]] in power. * 1886 - Telephone cables connect Lagos to London.<ref name=bradt4>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com.ng/books?id=fwuQ71ZbaOcC&pg=PA111&dq=|page=111|title=Nigeria: The Bradt Travel Guide|author=Lizzie Williams|publisher=Bradt Travel Guides|year=2008|isbn=978-1-841-6223-92}}</ref> * 1888 - [[Lagos Chamber of Commerce and Industry|Lagos Chamber of Commerce]] established.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xfHsJMBLWlsC&pg=PA14&dq=|title=The Advance of African Capital: The Growth of Nigerian Private Enterprise|publisher=University of Virginia Press|year=1994|isbn=978-0-813-9156-23|page=14}}</ref>{{sfn|Olukoju|2004}} * 1889 - Court House built.{{citation needed|date=September 2014}} * 1894 ** ''Lagos Echo'' and ''Lagos Standard'' [[List of newspapers in Nigeria|newspapers]] begin publication.<ref name="Omu2005">{{cite book|editor=Boniface I. Obichere|title=Studies in Southern Nigerian History |year= 2005|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-135-78108-8 |chapter= Newspaper Press in Southern Nigeria, 1880–1900 |author=Fred I.A. Omu |pages=101–124 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=c1KQAgAAQBAJ }}</ref> ** [[Bank of British West Africa]] established.<ref name=davies2002>{{cite web |url= http://projects.exeter.ac.uk/RDavies/arian/amser/chrono.html |title=Comparative Chronology of Money |author1= [[Glyn Davies (economist)|Glyn Davies]] |author2= Roy Davies |year=2002 |via=University of Exeter }}</ref> * 1898 - Electric street lighting commences operation.<ref name=bradt4/> * 1899 ** Anglo-African Bank established.{{sfn|Olukoju|2004}} ** Briton [[William MacGregor]] becomes governor of [[Lagos Colony]]. * 1900 - [[Ibadan]]-Lagos railway begins operating.<ref name="FalolaHeaton2008">{{cite book|author1= Toyin Falola |author2=Matthew M. Heaton|title=A History of Nigeria |year=2008|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-1-139-47203-6}}</ref>
==20th century== ===1901–1959=== [[File:Colonial era Lagos.png|thumb|400px|Colonial era Lagos, ca.1910]] [[File:Tennis Courts G.H. Lagos., ca.1910.png|thumb|Colonialists on the tennis courts Government House in Lagos., ca.1910]] [[Image:1912 Adimouruisha of Faro Ekin Lagos Nigeria by H Hunting of Paterson Zochonis 4545390321 University of Toronto.jpg|thumb|right|Lagos, 1912]] [[File:Lagos, 1929.jpg|thumb|300px|Aerial photograph of Lagos in 1929]]
* 1901 ** Oba [[Eshugbayi Eleko]] in power. ** [[Carter Bridge]] built. ** Lagos Institute founded.<ref name="Zachernuk2000">{{cite book|author=Philip Serge Zachernuk|title=Colonial Subjects: An African Intelligentsia and Atlantic Ideas|year=2000|publisher=University of Virginia Press|isbn=978-0-8139-1908-9 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=g7K6xlT50QkC |page=47+ |chapter='Sphinx Must Solve Her Own Riddle': New Imperialism and New Imperatives, 1880s-1920 }}</ref> ** Population: 41,487. * 1903 - Artist [[Aina Onabolu]] active.<ref name=MMA-afg11>{{cite web |url= http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/ht/?period=11&region=afg#/Key-Events |title= Guinea Coast, 1900 A.D.–present: Key Events |work= Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History |publisher=[[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] |location=New York |accessdate= 30 September 2015 }}</ref> * 1908 - Lagos Municipal Board of Health{{sfn|Tijani|2004}} and [[People's Union (Nigeria)|People's Union]]{{sfn|Sklar|1963}} established. * 1909 - [[King's College, Lagos]] founded.<ref name="Falola2009" /> * 1911 ** [[Kano]]-Lagos railway begins operating. ** [[Anti-Slavery and Aborigines Protection Society]] chapter established.{{sfn|Sklar|1963}} ** Population: 73,766. * 1913 - [[Apapa]] wharf built.{{sfn|Olukoju|2014}} * 1914 ** Lagos becomes capital of the British [[Colony and Protectorate of Nigeria]].<ref name=statesman1921>{{cite book |title=[[Statesman's Year-Book]] |year=1921 |location=London |publisher= Macmillan and Co.|chapter= British Empire: West Africa: Nigeria |chapterurl= http://hdl.handle.net/2027/njp.32101072368440?urlappend=%3Bseq=294 |via=HathiTrust }}</ref> ** ''Lagos Central Times'' [[List of newspapers in Nigeria|newspaper]] begins publication (approximate date). ** Anfani Bus Service begins operating.{{sfn|Forrest|1994}} * 1917 - Lagos Town Council<ref name="Falola2009chron" /> and Colonial Bank{{sfn|Olukoju|2004}} established. * 1920s - [[Lagos Market Women's Association]] founded.<ref name="Sheldon2005">{{cite book|author=Kathleen Sheldon|title=Historical Dictionary of Women in Sub-Saharan Africa |year= 2005|publisher=Scarecrow Press |isbn=978-0-8108-6547-1 |chapter=Chronology |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HMAeAgAAQBAJ }}</ref> * 1921 - Population: 98,303. * 1923 ** [[Ansar Ud Deen]] (religious group) and Lagos Women's League{{sfn|Fourchard|2012}} established. ** [[Nigerian National Democratic Party]] founded in Lagos.{{sfn|Sklar|1963}} * 1925 ** Oba Ibikunle Akitoye in power. ** ''[[Lagos Daily News]]'' newspaper begins publication.<ref name="Falola2001">{{cite book|author=Toyin Falola|title=Culture and Customs of Nigeria|year=2001|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-313-31338-7}}</ref> * 1926 ** ''[[Daily Times of Nigeria|Nigerian Daily Times]]'' newspaper begins publication.<ref name="Falola2001" /> ** Industrial Army Home (reformatory) built in Yaba.{{sfn|Fourchard|2012}} * 1927 - [[Queen's College, Lagos]] and Lagos Executive Development Board{{sfn|Tijani|2004}} established. * 1928 ** Oba Sanusi Olusi in power. ** [[St Gregory's College, Lagos]] and Lagos Book Club founded.<ref>{{Citation |publisher = Scarecrow Press |isbn = 0810820935 |publication-place = Metuchen, N.J |title = African Libraries |author = Glenn L. Sitzman |publication-date = 1988 |chapter=Nigeria }}</ref><ref name=olden1995 /> * 1930 - [[Onikan Stadium|Stadium]] built. * 1931 ** Tom Jones Library opens.<ref name=olden1995>{{Citation |publisher = Scarecrow Press |isbn = 0810830930 |publication-place = Lanham, Maryland |title = Libraries in Africa |author = Anthony Olden |publication-date = 1995 |chapter=The Lagos Library }}</ref> ** Population: 126,474. * 1932 ** Oba Falolu in power. ** [[Igbobi College]] and [[Yaba College|Yaba Higher College]] founded. * 1939 - [[Yaba, Lagos|Yaba]] Estate built. * 1943 - Art Exhibition Centre and Lagos Museum open.<ref name="Falola2009" /> * 1944 - Nigerian Women's Party organized in Lagos.<ref name="Sheldon2005" /><ref name="Okome2013">{{cite book|author=Mojúbàolú Olúfúnké Okome|title=Contesting the Nigerian State: Civil Society and the Contradictions of Self-Organization |year=2013|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|isbn=978-1-137-32453-5}}</ref> * 1945 - [[Holy Child College Obalende]] established. * 1946 ** Anglican [[Cathedral Church of Christ, Lagos|Cathedral]] built.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thecathedrallagos.org/cathedrals-history-1901-1950.php |title=Cathedral's History |publisher=Cathedral Church of Christ, Lagos |accessdate=17 June 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120902100051/http://www.thecathedrallagos.org/cathedrals-history-1901-1950.php |archivedate=2 September 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> ** [[Nigerian Breweries]] incorporated. * 1947 - [[Yaba College of Technology]] founded. * 1949 ** "Rent control committee" organized.{{sfn|Olukoju|2004}} ** Oba Adeniji Adele in power. * 1950 ** Mayoral council established; Abubakar Ibiyinka Olorun-Nimbe elected mayor.{{sfn|Tijani|2004}} ** [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Lagos]] active.<ref name=katolsk>{{cite web |title=Chronology of Catholic Dioceses: Nigeria |url= http://www.katolsk.no/organisasjon/verden/chronology/nigeria |work=www.katolsk.no |publisher=Oslo katolske bispedømme (Oslo Catholic Diocese) |location=Norway |accessdate=30 September 2014 }}</ref> * 1951 - Lagos becomes part of the [[Western Region, Nigeria|Western Region]]. * 1952 - Population: 267,407.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://unstats.un.org/unsd/demographic/products/dyb/1950_round.htm |work=Demographic Yearbook 1955 |year= |publisher=[[Statistical Office of the United Nations]] |location=New York |title=Population of capital city and cities of 100,000 or more inhabitants }}</ref> * 1957 ** [[Nigerian National Museum]] founded. ** ''Irohin Imole'' Yoruba-language newspaper begins publication.<ref>{{cite book |title=Africa South of the Sahara 2004 |series=Regional Surveys of the World |publisher= [[Europa Publications]] |year=2004 |isbn= 1857431839 |chapter= Nigeria: Directory |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jj4J-AXGDaQC |page=848+ }}</ref> * 1958 - [[Stationery Stores F.C.|Stationery Stores Football Club]] founded.
===1960–1999=== * 1960 - [[Nigerian Stock Exchange|Lagos Stock Exchange]] and [[Sterling Bank (Nigeria)|Nigeria Acceptances Limited]]. * 1961 - [[Nigerian Institute of International Affairs]] founded.<ref name=ISN>{{cite web |url=http://www.isn.ethz.ch/Digital-Library/Organizations |title=Organizations |work= [[International Relations and Security Network]] |location=Switzerland |publisher=[[Eidgenössische Technische Hochschule Zürich]] |accessdate=30 September 2014 }}</ref> * 1962 - [[University of Lagos]] established.<ref name="Falola2009chron" /> * 1963 ** [[Independence House]] built.{{sfn|Lonely Planet|1999}} ** Population: 655,246. * 1964 ** [[National Library of Nigeria]] built. ** Bagatelle restaurant in business (approximate date).{{sfn|Lonely Planet|1999}} ** [[Lebanese Community School]] established. * 1965 - [[Adeyinka Oyekan|Adeyinka Oyekan II]] becomes Oba. * 1967 ** [[Lagos State]] created.<ref name=unhabitat2004 /> ** [[Mobolaji Johnson]] becomes [[List of Governors of Lagos State|governor]] of Lagos State.<ref name=pastgovernorlist>{{cite web |url=http://www.lagosstate.gov.ng/pastgovernorlist.php?k=175 |accessdate=30 September 2014 |title=Past Governors |publisher=Lagos State Government |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141011065931/http://www.lagosstate.gov.ng/pastgovernorlist.php?k=175 |archivedate=11 October 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> * 1972 - [[Lagos National Stadium]] built. * 1973 - 2nd [[1973 All-Africa Games|All-Africa Games]] held. * 1975 ** [[Eko Bridge]] built. ** [[Federal Government College Lagos]] and [[Bridge Boys F.C.|Bridge Boys Football Club]] founded. ** [[Adekunle Lawal]] becomes [[List of Governors of Lagos State|governor]] of Lagos State.<ref name=pastgovernorlist /> ** Population: 1,060,848 city; 1,476,837 urban agglomeration.<ref>{{cite book |url= https://unstats.un.org/unsd/demographic/products/dyb/1970_round.htm |title=Demographic Yearbook 1975 |year=1976 |author=[[United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs]], Statistical Office |location=New York |chapter=Population of capital city and cities of 100,000 and more inhabitants |pages=253–279 }}</ref> * 1976 - [[National Arts Theatre]] built. * 1977 ** Second World African Festival of Arts and Culture held in [[Festac Town]].<ref name="Falola2009" /><ref name=MMA-afg11 /> ** Fela Kuti's [[Kalakuta Republic]] compound in Mushin burns down. ** [[Nigerian Institute of Medical Research]] established in Yaba (approximate date).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nimr-ng.org/NIMR-history.htm |title=Brief History |work=National Institute for Medical Research, Yaba, Lagos, Nigeria |accessdate=17 June 2012 }}</ref> ** [[Ndubuisi Kanu]] becomes [[List of Governors of Lagos State|governor]] of Lagos State.<ref name=pastgovernorlist /> * 1978 - [[Ebitu Ukiwe]] becomes [[List of Governors of Lagos State|governor]] of Lagos State.<ref name=pastgovernorlist /> * 1979 ** [[Murtala Muhammed International Airport]] opens. ** [[Lateef Jakande]] becomes [[List of Governors of Lagos State|governor]] of Lagos State.<ref name=pastgovernorlist /> * 1980 ** [[Badagry]]-Lagos [[Trans–West African Coastal Highway|highway]] constructed.<ref name=AFDB2003>{{citation |author1=[[Sweco]] |author2= Nordic Consulting Group |url=http://www.afdb.org/fileadmin/uploads/afdb/Documents/Project-and-Operations/00473227-EN-TAH-FINAL-VOL2.PDF |publisher=[[African Development Bank]] and [[United Nations Economic Commission for Africa]] |title=Review of the Implementation Status of the Trans African Highways and the Missing Links |volume= 2: Description of Corridors |year=2003 }}</ref> ** [[Lagos Plan of Action]] drafted.<ref name=unhabitat2004>{{cite book|title=State of the World's Cities 2004/2005: Globalization and Urban Culture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dxaCfKhlFpsC|year=2004|publisher=UN-HABITAT|isbn=978-92-1-131705-3}}</ref> ** [[Apata Memorial High School]] founded. ** Wonder Baking Company in business.{{sfn|Forrest|1994}} * 1981 ** [[International School Lagos]] established. ** [[Winners' Chapel]] megachurch begins. * 1982 - [[Indian Language School]] established. * 1983 ** ''[[Vanguard (Nigeria)|Vanguard]]'' newspaper begins publication. ** [[Mama Cass (restaurant)|Mama Cass restaurant]] in business.<ref>{{citation |url=http://dailyindependentnig.com/2014/02/competition-forces-mama-cass-to-shrink/ |date=February 2014 |title=Competition forces Mama Cass to shrink |work=[[The Daily Independent (Lagos)|Daily Independent]] |location=Lagos |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141110085621/http://dailyindependentnig.com/2014/02/competition-forces-mama-cass-to-shrink/ |archivedate=10 November 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> * 1984 - [[Gbolahan Mudasiru]] becomes [[List of Governors of Lagos State|governor]] of Lagos State.<ref name=pastgovernorlist /> * 1985 - ''[[Newswatch (Nigeria)|Newswatch]]'' magazine begins publication. * 1986 - [[Mike Akhigbe]] becomes [[List of Governors of Lagos State|governor]] of Lagos State.<ref name=pastgovernorlist /> * 1988 - [[Raji Rasaki]] becomes [[List of Governors of Lagos State|governor]] of Lagos State.<ref name=pastgovernorlist /> * 1989 ** [[1989 African Championships in Athletics|African Championships in Athletics]] held. ** [[Intercontinental Bank]] founded. * 1990 ** [[Third Mainland Bridge]] opens. ** [[Lagos City Polytechnic]] and [[Equitorial Trust Bank]] established. ** Population: 4,764,000 (urban agglomeration).<ref name=unhabitat2010 /> * 1991 ** Federal government relocates from Lagos to [[Abuja]].<ref name="Falola2009chron" /> ** ''[[Tell Magazine]]'' begins publication. ** [[Diamond Bank]] opens. ** [[Lagos Business School]] established. * 1992 ** [[Pepsi Football Academy]] founded, Agege.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pepsifootballacademy.com/history |title=History |publisher=Pepsi Football Academy |accessdate=17 June 2012 }}</ref> ** [[1992 Nigerian Air Force C-130 crash|Nigerian Air Force C-130 crash]]. ** [[Michael Otedola]] becomes [[List of Governors of Lagos State|governor]] of Lagos State.<ref name=pastgovernorlist /> * 1993 ** [[Jhalobia Recreation Park and Garden|Jhalobia Gardens]] opens.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.jhalobia.com/who_we_are_home2.html |title=History of Jhalobia Gardens |accessdate=17 June 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120730060632/http://www.jhalobia.com/who_we_are_home2.html |archivedate=30 July 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> ** [[Olagunsoye Oyinlola]] becomes [[List of Governors of Lagos State|governor]] of Lagos State.<ref name=pastgovernorlist /> * 1994 ** Chocolat Royal in business.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chocolatroyal.com/index.php/about-us |title=About Us |publisher=Chocolat Royal |location=Lagos |accessdate=30 September 2014 }}</ref> ** ''[[P.M. News]]'' newspaper begins publication. * 1995 ** ''[[Thisday]]'' newspaper begins publication. ** Population: 5,966,000 (urban agglomeration).<ref name=unhabitat2010 /> * 1996 ** [[Babington Macaulay Junior Seminary]] established. ** [[Tastee Fried Chicken]] opens in Surulere. ** [[Mohammed Buba Marwa]] becomes [[List of Governors of Lagos State|governor]] of Lagos State.<ref name=pastgovernorlist /> * 1997 ** [[Redeemer's International Secondary School]] founded in Maryland. ** [[Tantalizers]] restaurant opens in Festac Town (approximate date). * 1999 ** 20 February: [[Nigerian parliamentary election, 1999]] held. ** [[Bola Tinubu]] becomes [[List of Governors of Lagos State|governor]] of Lagos State.<ref name=pastgovernorlist /> * 2000 - **Population: 7,233,000 (urban agglomeration).<ref name=unhabitat2010 />

6399318233.jpg|thumb|right|Lagos, 2011]] * 2001 - ''[[The Daily Independent (Lagos)|The Daily Independent]]'' newspaper begins publication. * 2002 ** City divided "into 57 [[Lagos State#Administrative Divisions and Local Government Areas|local council areas]]."<ref name=unhabitat2004 /> ** [[Pan-African University, Lagos]] established. ** [[Lagos armoury explosion]]. * 2003 ** Oba [[Rilwan Akiolu]] in power. ** ''[[The Sun (Nigeria)|The Sun]]'' newspaper begins publication. * 2004 ** [[Spring Bank]] founded. ** Silverbird Cinema in business.<ref name=cinema>{{cite web |url= http://cinematreasures.org/theaters/nigeria/lagos?status=all |title=Movie Theaters in Lagos, Nigeria |work=CinemaTreasures.org |publisher= Cinema Treasures LLC |location=Los Angeles |accessdate=30 September 2014 }}</ref> * 2005 ** ''[[Business Day (Nigeria)|Business Day]]'' newspaper begins publication. ** [[SunRise Academy|SunRise Sixth Form College]] established. ** Population: 8,767,000 (urban agglomeration).<ref name=unhabitat2010>{{cite web |url=http://www.unhabitat.org/content.asp?cid=9141&catid=7&typeid=46 |title=The State of African Cities 2010: Governance, Inequalities and Metta]].{{sfn|Olukoju|2012}} * 2006 ** ''[[The Nation (Nigeria)|The Nation]]'' newspaper begins publication. ** Tin Can Island Port Complex formed.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nigerianports.org/AboutUsTinCanPort.aspx?id=3 |title= Tin Can Island Port Complex |author=Nigerian Ports Authority |authorlink=Nigerian Ports Authority |accessdate=17 June 2012 }}</ref> ** [[FinBank Nigeria|FinBank]] founded. ** [[Palms Shopping Mall]] opens. ** May - [[2006 Atlas Creek pipeline explosion|Atlas Creek pipeline explosion]]. ** December - [[2006 Abule Egba pipeline explosion|Abule Egba pipeline explosion]]. ** ''[[Mosunmola Abudu|Moments with Mo]]'' talk show begins broadcasting.{{sfn|New York Times|2014}} * 2007 ** April: [[Nigerian general election, 2007|State election]] held; [[Babatunde Fashola]] becomes [[List of Governors of Lagos State|governor]] of Lagos State.<ref>{{cite book|editor=Andreas Mehler|title=Africa Yearbook: Politics, Economy and Society South of the Sahara in 2007 |year= 2008 |volume=4 |publisher=Koninklijke Brill |isbn=9789004168053 |chapter=Nigeria |author=Heinrich Bergstresser |pages=151–166 (Nigeria)|Next]]'' newspaper begins publication. ** [[My People FC|My People Football Club]] founded. ** [[2008 Ijegun pipeline explosion|Ijegun pipeline explosion]]. * 2009 - Nike Centre for Art and Culture opens.{{sfn|New York Times|2014}} * 2010 ** [[Lagos Photo]] festival begins. ** Whitespace cultural venue active.{{sfn|Ogunbanwo|2015}} * 2011 ** [[Lagos Fashion Week]] begins.<ref>{{cite web |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131105144539/http://www.ariselive.com/about |archivedate=5 November 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> ** [[Enterprise Bank Limited]], [[Keystone Bank Limited]], and |editor=Lolade Adewuyi |via=Blogspot }}</ref> L'Espace (shop), and [[Google]] office<ref>{{cite web |publisher=Google Inc. |deadurl=yes |url=https://www.google.com/about/corporate/company/address.html }}</ref> in business. * 2012 ** [[Makoko]] slum razed.<ref>{{cite web |date= 17 July 2012 |title= Nigeria: Fury as Lagos State Government Demolishes #Makoko Slum |publisher=[[Global Voices Online|Global Voices]] }}</ref> ** [[Lagos Countdown]] begins. * 2013 ** [[Lekki-Ikoyi Link Bridge]] opens. ** [[Makoko Floating School]] built.<ref>{{citation |url= https://www.theguardian.com/cities/2015/jun/02/makoko-floating-school-lagos-waterworld-history-cities-50-buildings |title=Makoko Floating August: Helicopter crash in Oworonshoki.<ref>{{citation |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/08/13/us-nigeria-crash-idUSKCN0QH25I20150813 |date=13 August 2015 |title=Helicopter crashes into ===Published in 21st century=== ====2000s==== * {{cite book|editor=[[Okwui Enwezor]] |title=Under Siege: Four African Cities, Freetown, Johannesburg, Kinshasa, Lagos|year=2002 |isbn=978-3-7757-9090-1 |location=[[Ostfildern]], Germany |publisher= {{Interlanguage link multi|Hatje Cantz|de}} |quote=[[Documenta11]] }} + [http://www.documenta12.de/archiv/d11/data/english/platform4/index.html website] * {{cite book |title=Encyclopedia of Twentieth-Century African History |editor1= [[Paul Tiyambe Zeleza]] |editor2= Dickson Eyoh |publisher=Routledge |isbn=0415234794 |year=2003 |chapter= Lagos, Nigeria }} * {{cite book|editor= Toyin Falola |title=Nigerian Cities|year= 2004 |publisher=Africa World Press|isbn=978-1-59221-169-2 |chapter='New' Lagos Town Council and Urban Administration, 1950–1953 |author= Hakeem Tijani |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=JPJmCcZyxmYC |pages=255+ |display-editors=etal |ref= {{harvid|Tijani|2004}} }} * {{cite book|author= Ayodeji Olukoju |title=The 'Liverpool' of West Africa: The Dynamics and Impact of Maritime Trade in Lagos, 1900-1950|year= 2004 |publisher=Africa World Press|isbn=978-1-59221-292-7 |ref= {{harvid|Olukoju|2004}} }} * {{cite book|editor=Jürg Schneider|publisher = [[Museum der Kulturen Basel]] |title=Die Reisen Von {{Interlanguage link multi|Carl Passavant|de}} 1883–1885 |year=2005 |chapter= Lagos: Die Geburt einer Stadt |author= Ayodeji Olukoju |language=German |display-editors=etal }} * {{cite book|title=Encyclopedia of African History |publisher=Fitzroy Dearborn |isbn=978-1-57958-245-6 |editor= [[Kevin Shillington]] |year= 2005 |chapter= Lagos }} * {{cite book|author=[[Kristin Mann]]|title=Slavery and the Birth of an African City: Lagos, 1760-1900 |year=2007|publisher= [[Indiana University Press]] |isbn=0-253-11708-9 }}

revision.text:
{{Other uses|Zion (disambiguation)|Mount Zion (disambiguation)}} {{pp-move-indef}} [[File:Lieder des Ghetto 11.jpg|thumb|[[Ephraim Moses Lilien]], ''Zion'', 1903]] [[File:Lilien 1902.jpg|thumb|[[Ephraim Moses Lilien]], Stamp for the [[Jewish National Fund]], [[Vienna]], 1901-2. The symbolic design presents a [[Star of David]] containing the word Zion in the [[Hebrew alphabet]].]] [[File:Hahurva Painting.jpg|thumb|Mural by Nahum Meltzer, 2006-10.]] [[File:May our eyes behold your return in mercy to Zion.jpg|thumb|''May our eyes behold your return in mercy to Zion''. Design by [[Ephraim Moses Lilien|Lilien]] to the Fifth Zionist Congress, Basel, December 1901.<ref>Image published in ''Ost und West'', Berlin, January 1902, [http://sammlungen.ub.uni-frankfurt.de/cm/periodical/pageview/2585036 17-18].</ref>]]
'''Zion''' ({{lang-he|צִיּוֹן}} ''Ṣîyōn'', modern '''''Tsiyyon'''''; also [[Transliteration|transliterated]] ''Sion'', ''Sayon'', ''Syon'', ''Tzion'', ''Tsion'') is a [[toponymy|placename]] often used as a [[synonym]] for [[Jerusalem]]<ref name=Longmanp936/><ref name=Brileyp49/> as well as for the biblical [[Land of Israel]] as a whole. The word is first found in {{bibleref|2 Samuel|5:7}} which dates from c. 630–540 BCE according to modern scholarship. It originally referred to a specific hill in Jerusalem ([[Mount Zion]]), located to the south of [[Mount Moriah]] (the Temple Mount). Mount Zion held a [[Jebusite]] fortress of the same name that was conquered by [[David]] and was re-named the [[City of David]]; see [[Names of Jerusalem]]. That specific hill ("mount") is one of the many squat hills that form Jerusalem, which also includes Mount Moriah (the Temple Mount), the [[Mount of Olives]], etc. Over many centuries, until as recently as the Ottoman era, the city walls of Jerusalem were rebuilt many times in new locations, so that the particular hill known as Mount Zion is no longer inside the city wall, but its location is now just outside the portion of the Old City wall forming the southern boundary of the Jewish Quarter of the current Old City. Most of the original City of David itself is thus also outside the current city wall.
The term ''Tzion'' came to designate the area of Davidic Jerusalem where the fortress stood, and was used as well as [[synecdoche]] for the entire city of Jerusalem; and later, when [[Solomon's Temple]] was built on the adjacent Mount Moriah (which, as a result, came to be known as the Temple Mount) the meanings of the term ''Tzion'' were further extended by [[synecdoche]] to the additional meanings of the Temple itself, the hill upon which the Temple stood, the entire city of Jerusalem, the entire biblical Land of Israel, and "[[Jewish eschatology##.22The world to come.22|the World to Come]]", the Jewish understanding of the [[afterlife]].
In [[Kabbalah]], the more esoteric reference is made to Tzion being the spiritual point from which reality emerges, located in the [[Holy of Holies]] of the [[Solomon's Temple|First]], [[Second Temple|Second]] and [[Third Temple]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.shemayisrael.co.il/parsha/dimension/archives/devarim.htm|title=Parshas HaShavua|work=shemayisrael.co.il}}</ref>
==Etymology== The [[etymology]] of the word ''Zion'' (''ṣiyôn'') is uncertain.<ref name=Longmanp936>{{cite book|last1=Longman|first1=Tremper|authorlink1=Tremper Longman|last2=Enns|first2=Peter|authorlink2=Peter Enns|title=Dictionary of the Old Testament: Wisdom, Poetry & Writings: A Compendium of Contemporary Biblical Scholarship|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kE2k36XAkv4C&pg=PA936|year=2008|publisher=InterVarsity Press|isbn=978-0-8308-1783-2|page=936}}</ref><ref name=Brileyp49>{{cite book|last=Anderson|first=Arnold Albert|title=The book of Psalms|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eq5gFlzMxQgC|year=1981|publisher=Eerdmans|isbn=978-0-551-00846-5}}</ref><ref name=Bromileyp1006>{{cite book|last=Bromiley|first=Geoffrey W.|authorlink=Geoffrey W. Bromiley|title=The International Standard Bible Encyclopedia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yklDk6Vv0l4C&pg=PA1006|year=1995|publisher=Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing|isbn=978-0-8028-3782-0|page=1006}}</ref> Mentioned in the Old Testament in the [[Books of Samuel]] (2 Samuel 5:7) as the name of the [[Jebusite]] fortress conquered by [[David]], its origin likely predates the [[Israelites]].<ref name=Longmanp936/><ref name=Brileyp49/> If [[Semitic languages|Semitic]], it may be derived from the Hebrew root ''ṣiyyôn'' ("castle") or the Hebrew צִיָּה ''ṣiyya'' ("dry land", Jeremiah 51:43). A non-Semitic relationship to the [[Hurrian language|Hurrian]] word ''šeya'' ("river" or "brook") has also been suggested.<ref name=Bromileyp1006/>
===Orthography=== The form ''Tzion'' ({{lang-he|ציון}}; [[Tiberian vocalization]]: ''Ṣiyyôn'') appears 108 times in the [[Hebrew Bible]], and once as ''HaTzion''.<ref>''The Responsa Project: Version 13'', Bar Ilan University, 2005</ref> It is spelled with a [[tsade]] and not [[zayin]].<ref>Kline, D.E., ''A Comprehensive Etymological Dictionary of the Hebrew Language for readers of English'', Carta Jerusalem, The University of Haifa, 1987, pp.XII-XIII</ref>
The commonly used English form is based on [[German orthography]],<ref>Joseph Dixon, ''A general introduction to the Sacred Scriptures: in a series of dissertations, critical hermeneutical and historical'', J. Murphy, 1853, p.132</ref> where '''z''' is always pronounced [t͡s] (e.g. "zog" [t͡soːk]), hence "''Zion''" in German literature. A '''tz''' would only be used if the preceding vowel is short, hence the use of ''Zion'' in 19th-century German [[Biblical criticism]]. This orthography was adopted because in German, the correct transliteration can only be rendered from the one instance of ''HaTzion'' in Kings II 23:17, where the ''a'' vowel is followed by a double consonant '''tz'''.
==Judaism== Zion is the Hebrew name for a hill south of the Temple Mount in [[Jerusalem]], upon which was built the [[City of David]]. In its most specific sense, [[Mount Zion]] is not to be confused with [[Mount Moriah]], better known as the [[Temple Mount]], upon which the [[Temple of Solomon]] and the [[Second Temple]] were built. The location of the Temple, and in particular its [[Holy of Holies]] (innermost sanctum), is the most holy place in the world for the Jewish people, seen as the connection between [[God in Judaism|God]] and humanity. Observant Jews recite the [[Amidah]] three times a day facing the Temple Mount in Jerusalem, praying for the rebuilding of the Holy Temple, the restoration of the Temple service, the redemption of the world, and for the coming of the [[Messiah in Judaism|Messiah]].
===In the Tanakh=== <!-- This article is about the historical and religious term. Refs in pop culture belong in [[Zion (disambiguation)]] --> Some examples from the book of [[Psalms]], state: * "By the rivers of Babylon, there we sat down, yea, we wept, when we remembered Tzion." ([[Psalm 137]]:1) * "For there they that carried us away captive required of us a song; and they that wasted us ''required of us'' mirth, ''saying'', Sing us ''one'' of the songs of Tzion. How shall we sing the Lord's song in a strange land? If I forget thee, O Jerusalem, let my right hand forget ''her cunning''. If I do not remember thee, let my tongue cleave to the roof of my mouth; if I prefer not Jerusalem above my chief joy. Remember, O Lord, the children of Edom in the day of Jerusalem; who said, Raze ''it'', raze ''it'', even to the foundation thereof; O daughter of Babylon, that art to be destroyed; happy shall he be, that repayeth thee as thou hast served us." (Psalms 137:3-8, italics for words not in the original Hebrew) * "The Lord doth build up Jerusalem: he gathereth together the outcast of Israel. Praise the Lord, O Jerusalem; praise thy God, O Tzion." (Psalms 147:2,12)
===Daughter of Zion===<!-- This section is linked from [[Uncle Sam]] --> Mentioned 26 times in the [[Tanakh]], the biblical phrase "Daughter of Tzion" (Hebrew "bat Tzion") is not a reference to [[Moriah]] in Jerusalem, nor to the hill upon which the old [[City of David]] was built in the immediate south of [[Mount Moriah]], but rather to the women of the entire biblical [[Land of Israel]] and, thus, of [[Jewish peoplehood]] as a whole, including the [[Jewish diaspora]].
==Latter Day Saint movement== {{Main|Zion (Latter Day Saints)}} Within the [[Latter Day Saint movement]], Zion is often used to connote a [[utopia]]n association of the righteous. This association would practice a form of communitarian economics called the [[United Order]] meant to ensure that all members maintained an acceptable quality of life, class distinctions were minimized, and group unity achieved.{{Citation needed lead|date=January 2008}} While Zion has often been linked with [[theocracy]], the concept of Zion did not theoretically require such a governmental system.{{Citation needed lead|date=January 2008}} In this way, Zion must be distinguished from the ideal political system called [[theodemocracy]] which Latter Day Saints believed would be adopted upon Christ's [[Second Coming]].
==Arab and Islamic tradition== ''Ṣahyūn'' ({{lang-ar|صهيون}}, ''Ṣahyūn'' or ''Ṣihyūn'') is the word for Zion in Arabic and [[Syriac language|Syriac]].<ref name=PEFp21>{{cite book|author=Palestine Exploration Fund|authorlink=Palestine Exploration Fund|title=Palestine Exploration Quarterly|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nodAAQAAIAAJ|year=1977|publisher=Published at the Fund's Office|page=21}}</ref><ref name=Gilp114>{{cite book|last=Gil|first=Moshe|authorlink=Moshe Gil|title=A History of Palestine, 634-1099|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=M0wUKoMJeccC&pg=PA114|year=1997|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-59984-9|page=114}}</ref> Drawing on biblical tradition, it is one of the names accorded to Jerusalem in Arabic and Islamic tradition.<ref name=Gilp114/><ref name=Freundp141>{{cite book|last=Freund|first=Richard A.|title=Digging Through the Bible: Modern Archaeology and the Ancient Bible|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3EWWup0o-o4C&pg=PA141|year=2009|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|isbn=978-0-7425-4645-5|page=141}}</ref> A valley called ''Wādī Sahyũn'' seemingly preserves the name and is located approximately one and three-quarter miles from the [[Old City (Jerusalem)|Old City]]'s [[Jaffa Gate]].<ref name=PEFp21/>
For example, the reference to the "precious cornerstone" of the new Jerusalem in the [[Book of Isaiah]] 28:16 is identified in Islamic scholarship as the [[Black Stone]] of the [[Kaaba]].<ref name=Wheelerp89>{{cite book|last=Wheeler|first=Brannon M.|title=Moses in the Quran and Islamic Exegesis|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=By7D11xMzlcC&pg=PA89|year=2002|publisher=Psychology Press|isbn=978-0-7007-1603-6|page=89}}</ref> This interpretation is said by [[ibn Qayyim al-Jawziyya]] (1292–1350) to have come from the [[People of the Book]], though earlier Christian scholarship identifies the cornerstone with [[Jesus]].<ref name=Wheelerp89/>
==Rastafari movement== {{Rquote|right|I say fly away home to Zion, fly away home...One bright morning when my work is over, man will fly away home... |Rastaman Chant|[[Bob Marley and the Wailers|The Wailers]]|}} In [[Rastafari]], "Zion" stands for a [[utopia]]n place of unity, peace and freedom, as opposed to "[[Babylon]]", the oppressing and exploiting system of the materialistic modern world and a place of evil.<ref name="Oxford University Press">{{cite web|title=Definition of Babylon (chiefly among Rastafari)|url=http://oxforddictionaries.com/definition/american_english/Babylon--2|work=Oxford Dictionaries|publisher=Oxford University Press|accessdate=22 March 2013}}</ref>
It proclaims Zion, as reference to [[Ethiopia]], the original birthplace of humankind, and from the beginning of the movement calls to [[repatriation]] to Zion, the [[Promised Land]] and Heaven on Earth.<ref>{{cite web|title=What Do Rastafarians Believe|url=http://www.jamaicans.com/culture/rasta/believe.shtml|work=Jamaican Culture|publisher=Jamaicans.com|accessdate=22 March 2013|date=2003-05-30}}</ref> Some Rastafari believe themselves to represent the real [[Israelites|Children of Israel]] in modern times, and their goal is to repatriate to Ethiopia, or to Zion. The [[Ge'ez]]-language ''[[Kebra Nagast]]'' serves as inspiration for the idea that the "Glory of Zion" transferred from Jerusalem to Ethiopia in the time of Solomon and Sheba, c. 950 BC.
Rastafari [[reggae]] contains many references to Zion; among the best-known examples are the [[Bob Marley]] songs "Zion Train", "[[Iron Lion Zion]]", the [[Bunny Wailer]] song "Rastaman" ("The Rasta come from Zion, Rastaman a Lion!"), The Melodians song "Rivers of Babylon" (based on Psalm 137, where the captivity of ''Babylon'' is contrasted with the freedom in ''Zion''), the [[Bad Brains]] song "Leaving Babylon", the [[Damian Marley]] song featuring [[Nas]] "Road to Zion", [[The Abyssinians]]' "Forward Unto Zion" and [[Kiddus I]]'s "Graduation in Zion", which is featured in the 1977 cult roots rock reggae film ''[[Rockers (1978 film)|Rockers]]'', and "Let's Go to Zion" by [[Winston Francis]]. Reggae groups such as [[Steel Pulse]] and [[Cocoa Tea]] also have many references to Zion in their various songs.
==Zionism== {{Main|Zionism|Types of Zionism|Labor Zionism|Religious Zionism|Post-Zionism|Neo-Zionism}} [[File:Bat Zion I want your Old New Land join Jewish regiment.jpg|thumb|upright| Zion I want your Old New Land join Jewish regiment.jpg|thumb|A [[World War I]] recruitment poster. The Daughter of Zion (representing the Hebrew people): "Your [[The Old New Land|Old New Land]] must have you! Join the [[Jewish Legion|Jewish regiment]]."]]
The term "Zionism", coined by Austrian [[Nathan Birnbaum]], was derived from the German rendering of Tzion in his journal ''Selbstemanzipation'' (Self Emancipation) in 1890.<ref>De Lange, Nicholas, ''An Introduction to Judaism'', Cambridge University Press (2000), p. 30. {{ISBN|0-521-46624-5}}.</ref> Zionism as a [[Jewish political movements|political movement]] [[First Zionist Congress|started in 1897]] and supported a [[homeland|"national home"]], and [[Biltmore Conference|later a state]], for the [[Jew]]ish people in [[Palestine (region)|Palestine]]. The Zionist movement declared the re-establishment of its [[Israel|State of Israel]] in 1948, following the [[United Nations Partition Plan for Palestine]]. Since then and with varying [[ideologies]], Zionists have focused on developing and protecting this state.
The last line of the Israeli national anthem ''[[Hatikvah]]'' (Hebrew for "Hope") is "....Eretz Zion, ViYerushalayim", which means literally "The land of Zion and Jerusalem".
==Other uses== {{unreferenced section|date=March 2016}} The Jewish longing for Zion, starting with the deportation and enslavement of Jews during the [[Babylonian captivity]], was adopted as a metaphor by Christian black [[slavery|slaves]] in the [[United States]], and after the Civil War by blacks who were still oppressed. Thus, Zion symbolizes a longing by wandering peoples for a safe homeland. This could be an actual place such as [[Ethiopia]] for [[Rastafari movement|Rastafari]] or [[Israel]] for some of the [[Igbos]] in [[Nigeria]] for example. For others, it has taken on a more [[spirituality|spiritual]] meaning—a safe ''spiritual'' homeland, like in [[heaven]], or a kind of [[inner peace|peace of mind]] in one's present life.
==Mount Zion today== [[File:Dormitio Jerusalem.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Abbey of the Dormition]] on the modern Mount Zion.]] Today, [[Mount Zion]] refers to a hill south of the Old City's [[Armenian Quarter]], not to the Temple Mount. This apparent misidentification dates at least from the 1st century AD, when [[Josephus]] calls Jerusalem's Western Hill "Mount Zion".<ref name=Pixner>{{cite book|last=Pixner|first=Bargil|authorlink=Bargil Pixner|title=Paths of the Messiah and Sites of the Early Church from Galilee to Jerusalem: Jesus and Jewish Christianity in Light of Archaeological Discoveries|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bvhA6IE4VqgC&pg=PA321|year=2010|publisher=Ignatius Press|isbn=978-0-89870-865-3|page=321}}</ref> The [[Abbey of the Dormition]] is located upon the hill currently called Mount Zion.
